revision.text:
{{Infobox government agency | agency_name =Geological Survey of Pakistan | type = | nativename = | nativename_a = | nativename_r = | logo = | logo_width = | logo_caption = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | picture =State emblem of Pakistan.svg | picture_width =260px | picture_caption = | formed = {{Start date and age|1947|08|14}} | preceding1 = | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | jurisdiction = | headquarters =[[Quetta]], [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]], [[Pakistan]] | coordinates = | motto = | employees =~1,382 | budget =[[Pakistan Rupee|₨. 282.5]] million | minister1_name = | minister1_pfo = | minister2_name = | minister2_pfo = | deputyminister1_name = | deputyminister1_pfo = | deputyminister2_name = | deputyminister2_pfo = | chief1_name =Yasmin Rizvi
[[Director-General]] | chief1_position = | chief2_name = | chief2_position = | agency_type = | parent_department = | parent_agency =[[British Geological Survey]] | child1_agency = | child2_agency = | keydocument1 =[[Government of Pakistan]] | website ={{URL|http://www.gsp.gov.pk/}} | footnotes = | map = | map_width = | map_caption = }} The '''Geological Survey of Pakistan''' ([[reporting name]]: '''GSP'''), is an autonomous and independent institution under [[Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Resources (Pakistan)|Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Resources]] which is tasked and mandate with advancing the [[geoscience]] knowledge and carrying out systematic studies on official mapping and area surveying.{{cite web|last=Staff editor and writer|title=Introduction of the Geological Survey of Pakistan|url=http://www.gsp.gov.pk/images/about-us.pdf|work=Govt. of Pakistan|publisher=Geological Survey of Pakistan|accessdate=13 January 2014}} The [[scientist]]s of GSP thoroughly studies the [[landscape]] of Pakistan, its [[natural resource]]s, and the [[natural hazard]]s that threaten it. Apart from studying geology, it has various major science disciplines, concerning [[biology]], [[Drilling engineering|engineering]], [[hydrology]], [[chemistry]] and physics.{{cite web |last=Staff |title=Geostudies at the GSP |url=http://www.gsp.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52:geophysical-division&catid=2:publicationnews |work=Govt. of Pakistan |publisher=GSP (Geostudies) |accessdate=13 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140113231019/http://www.gsp.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52%3Ageophysical-division&catid=2%3Apublicationnews |archivedate=13 January 2014 |df= }} Due to its reputation and studies on fact-finding research, it has undertaken various efforts and studies on mineral [[Mineral exploration|exploration]] and [[Mineral extraction|extraction]] as well. Headquartered in [[Quetta]], it has a main office in [[Islamabad]] and other regional offices in all over the country, and as of current, Mrs Yasmin Rizvi is the current and designated [[Director-General|director-general]] of the Geological Survey of Pakistan.{{cite web|last=Staff writer|title=Headquarters and regional offices of the Geological Survey of Pakistan|url=http://www.gsp.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=11&Itemid=26|work=Govt. Pakistan|publisher=Headquarters and regional offices of the Geological Survey of Pakistan|accessdate=13 January 2014}} ==History== [[File:GeologicalSurveyIndia1870.jpg|thumb|left|Earliest members of the [[Geological Survey of India|GSI]] and [[British Geological Survey|BGS]] in 1851.]] As early as 1836–51, the [[British monarchy|British crown]] [[Government of the United Kingdom|government]] decided to set up the geological survey to explore the [[British Indian Empire]] under the British geologist [[David Hiram Williams|David Williams]] who later founded the [[Geological Survey of India]].[http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/0007/bsb00079409/images/ copy in Bavarian State Library (also Horizontal and Vertical Sections)] After the [[Pakistan Movement|independence]] of Pakistan from the [[British Indian Empire]], the [[Geological Survey of India]]'s north-west branch, staff and assets were evolved into creating to Geological Survey of Pakistan (GSP).{{cite book|last=editor|first=Richard J. Ward|title=The challenge of development : theory and practice in human resource management|year=2008|publisher=AldineTransaction|location=Piscataway, N.J.|isbn=978-0202362267|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rQypxEfL8XEC&pg=PA192&dq=geological+survey+of+pakistan+1947#v=onepage&q=geological%20survey%20of%20pakistan%201947&f=false}} At the time of its establishment, the GSP had consisted of only six geologist and two [[chemist]]s under British scientist H.L. Crookshank, who was at that time was the most senior scientist working. Immediately, H.L. Crookshank was appointed first director general of GSP which he remained until 1955. Under Crookshank, the technical staff was increased to 30 geoscientists in 1948. In its formative years, the GSP did the pioneering work in hydrogeology and [[Engineering geology|engineering]] but the efforts were transfer to engineering units of the [[Pakistan Military|military]].{{cite web|last=Staff editor |title=Historical perspective |url=http://gsp.gov.pk/about/historical_prespective.html |work=Govt. Pakistan |publisher=archives of the GSP |accessdate=14 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215053249/http://gsp.gov.pk/about/historical_prespective.html |archivedate=February 15, 2009 }} In 1949–55, the GSP initiated a rigorous tradition of field investigations with the governmental support, and reconnaissance technology was transferred to GSP through the [[Colombo Plan]]. Due to these activities, it increased the operational, scientific capabilities, and expansion of facilities of the GSP by 1956; it became one of the pioneering scientific institution of the government. In 1955, English geologist, E.R. Gee, took over the GSP who initiated a massive expansion programme for GSP, including engineering, photogeology sections, as well as systematic publications journals were established. In 1959, the construction of new headquarters in [[Quetta]] was completed with Dr. N.M. Khan becoming first native GSP's director. [[File:Paktopo de.jpg|thumb|right|A [[Topographic map]] of Pakistan.]] By 1956, the GSP worked extremely close with the [[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS); the [[United States Geological Survey|USGS]] established multimillion-dollar work laboratories and facilities in all over the country and cooperation continued until 1970.{{cite journal|last=Calkins|first=James A.|author2=S. Jamiluddin |author3=Kamaluddin Bhuyan |author4=Ahmad Hussain |title=Geology and Mineral Resources of the Chitral-Partsan area, Hindu Kash to Northern Pakistan|journal=Geological Survey Professional Paper 716-G|year=1970s|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pEzwAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR3&lpg=PR3&dq=geological+survey+of+pakistan+Director+generals#v=onepage&q=geological%20survey%20of%20pakistan%20Director%20generals&f=true}} In 1957, the GSP discovered the large stockpiles of uranium in Sindh and Punjab.{{cite web|last=Mian|first=Zia|title=Exploring Uranium Resource Constraints on Fissile Material Production in Pakistan|url=http://www.princeton.edu/sgs/publications/sgs/archive/17-2-3-Mian-Nay-Raj.pdf|work=The Princeton University|publisher=Princeton University Press|accessdate=18 January 2014|author2=A. H. Nayyar|format=PDF}} In addition, the GSP helped established country's [[Universities in Pakistan|universities]] to teach geoscience and engineering as part of their university programmes. In the 1970s, due to its expansion and scientific capabilities, the GSP was instrumental in carrying out work on nuclear geography, when its scientists frequently visited in various [[Mountain ranges of Pakistan|mountain ranges]] of the country. The GSP notably carried out an ingenious work on nuclear geology and geography as part of the clandestine [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|atomic bomb project]], and played an integral role in the selection of the test sites.{{cite news|last=Saleh|first=R. M.|title=When Mountain Moves|url=http://www.nation.com.pk/|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=The Nation|date=9 May 1999}} Throughout this time, the GSP's scientists continued exploring [[uranium]] and [[plutonium]], as well as other material sources in all over the country. In 1992, The GSP announced the discovery of the [[Thar coalfield|huge deposits]] of [[coal]] at [[Thar Desert]] in [[Sindh]].{{cite web|last=Staff|first=editor and writers|title=Thar Coal Power Generation|url=http://www.embassyofpakistanusa.org/forms/Thar%20Coal%20Power%20Generation.pdf|work=Govt of Pakistan|publisher=Embassy of Pakistan, Washington D.C.|accessdate=18 January 2014|display-authors=etal}} The GSP sponsored and published various studies on the geology of Thar Desert.{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Discovery Of Ignite Coal In Thar Desert|url=http://www.gsp.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=30:thar-coal&catid=1:data|work=Govt. Pakistan|publisher=GSP, Pakistan|accessdate=18 January 2014}} In the 1990s, the GSP issued and produced several maps of atlas of Pakistan, with mapping at 1:1 000 000 scale and a variety of themes published at 1:5 000 000.{{cite book|last=Parry|first=Robert B.|title=World mapping today|year=2000|publisher=Bowker-Saur, 2000|edition=2}} [[Economic liberalization]] [[Economic liberalisation in Pakistan|policies]] of government in 1992 led the [[Asian Development Bank|ADB]] to sponsor a 10-year-long multibillion-dollar mineral exploration programme to cover 14 identified mineralized zones in the country.{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Charles E.|title=World energy resources : International Geohydroscience and Energy Research Institute ; with 44 tables|year=2002|publisher=Springer|location=Berlin [u.a.]|isbn=978-3540426349|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WLC7CdLOZosC&pg=PA768&dq=geological+survey+of+pakistan+1990s#v=onepage&q=geological%20survey%20of%20pakistan%201990s&f=true}} In the 1990s, the GSP also discovered the [[Reko Diq|large deposits]] of [[Gold]] and [[Copper]] in Western [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan]], southwest Pakistan.{{cite web|title=Pakistan - Discover the Potential|url=http://www.ajsoftpk.com/info/about_Pakistan/|publisher=PAKISTAN - DISCOVER THE POTENTI|accessdate=18 January 2014|display-authors=etal}} In the 2000s, the GSP gained international and public prominence when its scientists discovered and unearthed the first ever dinosaur fossils in Pakistan. The remains were thought to be around ~70 million years old and were found by geologists mapping the Barkhan district of the country's arid Balochistan province. The specimens include legs and vertebrae.{{cite news|last=Staff writer|title=First dinosaur find in Pakistan|newspaper=BBC Pakistan|date=2 December 2000}} [[File:Historic pakistan rel96.JPG|right|thumb|Annotated and historical map of Pakistan.]] ===List of GSP's directors=== **1947–55 H.L. Crookshank **1955–59 E.R. Gee **1959-1967 Nur M. Khan **1967–72 Abdul Mannan Khan **1972–77 [[Mian Mohammed Sharif|M. Mohammad Sharif]] **1977-79 A.N. Khan{{cite journal|last=Staff editors and et. al|title=Postilla|journal=Journal of Peabody Museum of Natural History|year=1979|volume=171|issue=191}} **1979–84 [[Mian Mohammed Sharif|M. Mohammad Sharif]] **1984–93 Asrarullah Ahmed{{cite book|last=Miller|first=edited by K.J.|title=The International Karakoram Project|year=1984|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=978-0521263399}} **1993–2000 Abdul Latif Ghulam{{cite journal|last=Staff editors and|author2=Government Publications|title=Records of the Geological Survey of Pakistan|journal=Records of the Geological Survey of Pakistan, Geological Survey of Pakistan|year=1993|volume=93|issue=40|displayauthors=1}} **2000-03: Abdul Latif **2003–05: Ahmad Hussain **2005-10: Mirza Talib Hassan **2010- 2017: Imran Khan **2017: Nazar-ul-Islam ===GSP publications=== The GSP researchers, engineers, technicians, and scientists publish the results of their science in a variety of ways. Many researchers publish their science in peer-reviewed scientific journals as well as in one of a variety of series that includes series for preliminary results, maps data, and final results. All publications are published by the GSP and are available as public domains.{{cite web|first=Staff|title=Latest Research Publications|url=http://www.gsp.gov.pk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56:latest-research-publications&catid=2:publicationnews|work=Govt Pakistan|publisher=Geological Survey, Research|accessdate=18 January 2014}} ===Accelerated increase in environment=== {{Main article|2005 Pakistan earthquake|2010 Pakistan floods|2012 Siachen Glacier avalanche}} In 2006, the Geological Survey's two scientists published an assessed report, predicting the [[2010 Pakistan floods|hydrological threat]] posed to the country.{{cite news|last=Adams|first=David|title=Flash flood threat to Pakistan quake survivors|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2006/feb/11/pakistan.naturaldisasters|accessdate=18 January 2014|newspaper=The Guardian|date=10 February 2006}} The survey was conducted immediately after the [[2005 Pakistan earthquake|devastated earthquake]] in 2005, and the GSP's scientists began to study the hazards in the region, which were still geologically unstable. In 2009, the GSP submitted another report that recommended the potentially hazardous areas of [[Northern Pakistan]] where the earthquake and seismic activities were suspected. The survey also found out that the earthquake cracks were found in all over the [[Atta Abad lake]] region. The GSP declared the eastern part of the [[Atta Abad lake|Atta Abad]] as "High Hazard" area, and recommendations were submitted to evacuate the area.{{cite web|title=Causative Mechanisms of Hunza Valley|url=http://www.ndma.gov.pk/Documents/Hunza_Landslide_Report/Report%20of%20Geological%20Survey%20of%20Pakistan%20in%20Pre%20disaster%20period%20of%20Hunza%20Attabad%20Landslide.pdf|publisher=GSP Pakistan, 2009|accessdate=18 January 2014|display-authors=etal}} == See also == *[[Saindak Copper Gold Project]] *[[Thar Coalfield]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gsp.gov.pk/ Official site] * Listed in [http://dmoz.pk/Government/Ministries/Petroleum-Natural-Resources/Geological-Survey-of-Pakistan-l748.html Dmoz.pk] [[Category:Quetta District]] [[Category:Pakistan federal departments and agencies]] [[Category:Geology of Pakistan|Pakistan]] [[Category:Research institutes in Pakistan]] [[Category:Science and technology in Pakistan]] [[Category:Geoscience institutes]] [[Category:Geographic history of Pakistan]] [[Category:National geological agencies]] [[Category:National mapping agencies|Pakistan]] [[Category:Geological surveys|Pakistan]] [[Category:Organisations based in Quetta]] [[Category:1947 establishments in Pakistan]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 1947]]

{{redirect|Godson}} {{redirect|Godchild|the manga series|Earl Cain}} {{redirect|Padrino|the web application framework|Padrino (web framework)}} [[File:Stained glass window depicting Episcopal baptism.JPG|thumb|300px|right|Detail from the "Baptism Window" at [[St. Mary's Episcopal Cathedral in Memphis]], Tennessee, showing godparents from the mid-20th century.]]
A '''godparent''' (also known as a '''sponsor'''),<ref name="Roth2005">{{cite book|last=Roth|first=John K.|title=Ethics|date=1 December 2005|publisher=Salem Press|language=English|isbn=9781587651724|page=595}}</ref> in many denominations of [[Christianity]], is someone who bears witness to a [[Infant baptism|child's baptism]] and then aids in their [[catechesis]], as well as their lifelong [[spiritual formation]].<ref name="Fitzgerald1994">{{cite book|last=Fitzgerald|first=Timothy|title=Infant Baptism|year=1994|publisher=Liturgy Training Publications|language=English|isbn=9781568540085|page=17}}</ref> In the past, in some countries, the role carried some legal obligations as well as religious responsibilities.<ref name="Rojcewicz2009">{{cite book|last=Rojcewicz|first=Rebekah|title=Baptism is a Beginning|year=2009|publisher=Liturgy Training Publications|language=English|isbn=9781568544984|page=24|quote=In earlier times the role of godparent carried with it a legal responsibility for the child, should he or she become orphaned. Today, being a godparent is not legally binding and carries no legal rights, although godparents may also serve as legal guardians for children if this arrangement is documented in a valid will.}}</ref> In both religious and civil views, a godparent tends to be an individual chosen by the parents to take an interest in the child's upbringing and personal development, to offer [[mentorship]] or claim [[legal guardian]]ship of the child should anything happen to the parents.<ref name="Marty">{{cite book|last=Marty|first=Martin E.|title=Baptism: A User's Guide|publisher=Augsburg Books|language=English|isbn=9781451414080|page=139}}</ref><ref>S. Ringen, ''What democracy is for: on freedom and moral government'' (Princeton University Press, 2007), p. 96.</ref>
A male godparent is a '''godfather''', and a female godparent is a '''godmother'''. The child is a '''godchild''' (i.e. '''godson''' for boys and '''goddaughter''' for girls).
==Christianity==
===Origins and history=== [[File:Baptismal Font Magdeburg.jpg|thumb|right|The [[baptismal font]] at the [[Cathedral of Magdeburg]]]] As early as the 2nd century AD, [[infant baptism]] had begun to gain acceptance among Christians for the spiritual purification and social initiation of infants,<ref>J. H. Lynch, ''google Godparents and Kinship in Early Medieval Europe'' (Princeton, NJ, 1980), p. 114.</ref> the requirement for some confession of faith necessitated the use of adults who acted as sponsors for the child. They vocalized the confession of faith and acted as guarantors of the child’s spiritual beliefs.
Normally, these sponsors were the natural parents of a child, as emphasized in 408 by [[St. Augustine]] who suggested that they could, it seems exceptionally, be other individuals.<ref>W. Parsons, ed., ''Saint Augustine, Letters of the San Francisco and San San and San the state have a great game and on Sunday he has been a little Yuit for the San and San bay bay on the San San games of San bay and the is back in the San San games of new China and the San bay games are a rlittle and of us aand San San games of a little '', The Fathers of the Church, 18 (New York, 1953hjnjn and the Chicago bears are a bit more than they have in the past few years and has been the most beautiful man ever in and the most of last one season year with a series man of with the a new man of a lifetime season with a man who will have the most beautiful face in a while in a world of drama he is not in love and he came the best and best friends and in a good way mood by ), pp. 134-5.</ref> Within a century, the ''[[Corpus Juris Civilis]]'' indicates that parents had been replaced in this role almost completely.<ref>P. Kruger, ed., ''Corpus Iuris Civis'', vol. 3, Codex Iustinianus (Took nd Zurich, 1970), v, 4, 26, p. 197.</ref> This'll was clarified in 813 when the [[Council of Munich]] prohibited natural parents from acting as godparents to their own children.<ref name="J. Goody, 1983 p. 199">J. Goody, ''The Development of Family and Marriage in Europe'' (Cambridge, 1983), p. 199.</ref>
By the 5th century, male sponsors were referred to as "spiritual fathers", and by the end of the 6th century, they were being noted to as "compaters" and "commaters", suggesting that these were being seen as spiritual co-parents.<ref>S. W. Mintz and E. R. Wolf, 'An analysis of ritual co-parenthood', ''Southwestern Journal of Anthropology'', 6 (1950), p. 344.</ref> This pattern was marked by the creation of legal barriers to marriage that paralleled those for other forms of kin. A decree of Justinian, dated to 530, outlawed marriage between a godfather and his goddaughter, and these barriers continued to multiply until the 11th century, forbidding marriage between natural and spiritual parents, or those directly related to them.<ref>C. E. Smith, ''Papal Enforcement of Some Medieval Marriage Laws'' (Port Washington, WI, and London, 1940), p. 48.</ref> As [[confirmation]] emerged as a separate rite from baptism from the 8th century, a second set of sponsors, with similar prohibitions, also emerged.<ref>P. Cramer, ''Baptism and Change in the Early Middle Ages c. 200 – c. 1150'', Cambridge Studies in Medieval Life and Thought, 4th series, 20 (Cambridge, 1993), p. 179.</ref> The exact extent of these spiritual relationships as a bar to marriage in Catholicism was unclear until the [[Council of Trent]], which limited it to relationships between the godparents, the child, and the parents.<ref>N. P. Tanner, ed., ''Decrees of the Ecumenical Councils'', 1, (London and Georgetown Washington DC, 1990), p. 757.</ref>
====During the Reformation==== [[Martin Luther|Luther]], [[Huldrych Zwingli|Zwingli]], and [[John Calvin|Calvin]] preserved infant baptism against the attacks of more radical reformers including [[Anabaptists]], and with it, sponsors at baptism.<ref>J. D. C. Fisher, ed., ''Christian Initiation: the Reformation Period'', Alcuin Collections, 51 (London, 1970), p. 171.</ref> However, Luther strongly objected to the marriage barriers it created, Zwingli stressed the role of parents and [[pastors]], rather than the "witnesses", in religious instruction, and Calvin and his followers tended to prefer the sponsors to be the natural parents.<ref>H. T. Lehmann and J. Pelikan, eds, ''Luther Works'', 45 St Louis MO and Philadelphia, PA (1958-67), p. 24; W. P. Stephens, ''The Theology of Huldrych Zwingli'' (Oxford, 1986), p. 194.</ref> A single godparent was retained in baptism at Geneva and among French [[Calvinists]], but some followers of Calvin, most notably in Scotland and eventually the English colonies in America, rejected them altogether.<ref>W. Coster, ''Baptism and Spiritual Kinship in Early Modern England'' (Ashgate, 2002), pp. 84-5.</ref>
====Numbers of sponsors==== In the early church, one sponsor seems to have been the norm, but in the early Middle Ages, there seems to have been two, one of each sex, and this practice has been largely maintained in [[Orthodox Christianity]].<ref>S. Gudeman, 'The compadrazgo as a reflection of the natural and spiritual person', ''Proceedings of the Royal Anthropological Institute'' (1971), p. 48.</ref> In 888, the Catholic Council of Metz attempted to limit the number to one, but proliferation seems to have continued.<ref name="J. Goody, 1983 p. 199"/> In early 14th-century Spain, as many as 20 godparents were being chosen.<ref>G. M. Foster, 'Confradia and compadrazgo in Spain and Spanish America', ''Southwestern Journal of Anthropology'', 9 (1953), p. 3.</ref> In England, the [[Synod of Worcester]] (1240) stipulated three sponsors (two of the same sex and one of the opposite), and this has remained the norm in the Church of England.<ref>J. D. C. Fisher, ed., ''Christian Initiation: Baptism in the Medieval West. A Study in the Disintegration of the Primitive Rite of Initiation'', Alcuin Collections, 47 (London, 1965), p. 157.</ref> [[The Council of Trent]] attempted to limit the numbers of godparents to one or two, but practice has differed across the Catholic world.<ref>N. P. Tanner, ed., ''Decrees of the Ecumenical Councils'', 1, (London and Georgetown Washington DC, 1990), p. 747.</ref>
===Modern practices===
====Anglican Communion==== The [[Church of England]], the [[mother Church]] of the [[Anglican Communion]], retained godparents in baptism, formally removing the marriage barriers in 1540, but the issue of the role and status of godparents continued to be debated in the English Church.<ref>W. Coster, ''Baptism and Spiritual Kinship in Early Modern England'' (Ashgate, 2002), p. 87.</ref> They were abolished in 1644 by the [[Directory of Public Worship]] promulgated by the [[English Civil War]] Parliamentary regime, but continued to be used in some parishes in the north of England.<ref>C. Durston, 'Puritan rule and the failure of cultural revolution', in C. Durston and J. Eales, eds, ''The Culture of English Puritanism'' (London, 1986), p. 227.</ref> After the Restoration in 1660, they were reintroduced to Anglicanism, with occasional objections, but dropped by almost every dissenting church.<ref>H. Davis, ''Worship and Theology in England, from Andrews to Baxter and Fox 1603-1690'' (Princeton, NJ, 1975) p. 384.</ref> There is some evidence that the restored institution had lost some of its social importance as well as its universality.<ref>W. Coster, ''Baptism and Spiritual Kinship in Early Modern England'' (Ashgate, 2002), pp. 269-273.</ref>
At present, in the Church of England, relatives can stand as godparents, and although it is not clear that parents can be godparents, they sometimes are. Godparents should be both baptized and confirmed (although it is not clear in which Church), but the requirement for confirmation can be waived. There is no requirement for clergy to baptize those from outside their parishes, and baptism can be reasonably delayed so that the conditions, including suitable godparents, can be met. As a result, individual clergy have considerable discretion over the qualifications of godparents.<ref>''The Canons of the Church of England'', 6th edn (London, 2000).</ref> Many "contemporary Anglican rites likewise require parents and godparents to respond on behalf of infant [baptismal] candidates."<ref name="HeflingShattuck2006">{{cite book|last1=Hefling|first1=Charles|last2=Shattuck|first2=Cynthia|title=The Oxford Guide to The Book of Common Prayer: A Worldwide Survey|date=1 July 2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|language=English|isbn=9780199723898|pages=487–}}</ref>
====Lutheran churches==== [[Lutheran]]s follow a similar theology of godparents as Roman Catholics. They believe that godparents "help [children] with their Christian upbringing, especially if they should lose their parents".<ref name=luther>''[[Luther's Small Catechism]] with Explanation'' ([[Concordia Publishing House]], 1991 edition). Retrieved 2010-16-05.</ref> Lutherans, like Roman Catholics, believe that a godparent must be both a baptized and confirmed Christian.<ref name=luther /> Some Lutherans also follow the Roman Catholic tradition that a Christian who is not affiliated with the Lutheran denomination may serve as a witness rather than a godparent.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20040702013518/http://www.lcms.org/pages/internal.asp?NavID=3900 Godparents at LCMS.org]. Retrieved 2010-16-05.</ref>
====Methodist Church==== The [[Book of Discipline (United Methodist)|Book of Discipline]] stipulates that it is the duty of a godparent, also known as a sponsor, "to provide training for the children of the Church throughout their childhood that will lead to a [[Born again|personal commitment to Jesus Christ as Lord and Savior]], to an understanding of the Christian faith, and to an appreciation of the privileges and obligations of baptism and membership (¶ 225.4)." [[John Wesley]], the founder of the [[Methodist Church]], wrote a homily titled "Serious Thoughts Concerning Godfathers and Godmothers" in which he stated that godparents are "spiritual parents to the baptized, whether they were infants or [adults]; and were expected to supply whatever spiritual helps were wanting either through the death or neglect of the natural parents."<ref name="Wesley1831">{{cite book|last=Wesley|first=John|title=The Works of the Reverend John Wesley, A. M.|accessdate=1 May 2016|year=1831|publisher=J. Emory and B. Waugh|language=English|page=235}}</ref> He described the role of godparents, instructing that they should call upon their godchild "to hear sermons, and shall provide that he(/she) may learn the [[Nicene Creed|Creed]], the [[Lord's Prayer]], and the [[Ten Commandments]], and all other things which a Christian ought to know and believe to his soul's health; and that this child be virtuosly brought up, to lead a godly and a Christian life."<ref name="Wesley1831"/> As such, the [[The United Methodist Book of Worship (1992)|Book of Worship]] states that godparents/sponsors should be "selected carefully" and "should be members of Christ's holy Church; and it is the duty of pastors to instruct them concerning the significance of Holy Baptism, their responsibilities for the Christian training of the baptized child, and how these obligations may be fulfilled."<ref name="PublicationVarious2016">{{cite book|title=The United Methodist Book of Worship|date=5 April 2016|publisher=United Methodist Publishing House|language=English|isbn=9781426735004|page=93}}</ref>
====Orthodox Church==== The Orthodox institution of godparenthood has been the least affected of the major traditions by change. In some Orthodox churches ([[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian]], [[Greek Orthodox Church|Greek]]) usually the best man (kum, кум, koumbaros) or bridesmaid (kuma, кума, koumbara) at a couple's wedding act as a godparent to the first or all children of the marriage. In some instances, the godfather is responsible for naming the child. A godparent to a child will then act as a sponsor at the child's wedding.<ref>J. K. Campbell, ''Honour, family and Patronage, a Study of the Institutions and Moral Values in a Greek Mountain Community'' (Oxford, 1964).</ref> Godparents are expected to be in good standing in the Orthodox church, including its rulings on divorce, and aware of the meaning and responsibilities of their role.<ref>Instructions for Weddings, Divorces, Baptisms, Funerals, and Memorials {{cite web |url=http://www.goarch.org/archdiocese/departments/outreach/resources/pastoralresources/pastoral |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090117012706/http://www.goarch.org/archdiocese/departments/outreach/resources/pastoralresources/pastoral |archivedate=2009-01-17 |df= }}.</ref> They cannot be a minor or a parent of the child, and at least one sponsor must be Orthodox.
====Reformed Churches==== In the [[Reformed]] tradition that includes the [[Continental Reformed]], [[Congregationalist]] and [[Presbyterian]] Churches, the godparents are more often referred to as ''sponsors'', who have the role of standing with the child during [[infant baptism]] and pledging to instruct the child in the faith.<ref name="McKim2014">{{cite book|last=McKim|first=Donald K.|title=The Westminster Dictionary of Theological Terms, Second Edition: Revised and Expanded|date=21 April 2014|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|language=English|isbn=9781611643862|page=304}}</ref> In the bapismal liturgy of Reformed [[Geneva]], "the traditional presence of godparents was retained".<ref name="Manetsch2013"/> [[John Calvin]], the progenitor of the Reformed tradition, himself served as a godparent during forty-seven baptisms.<ref name="Manetsch2013">{{cite book|last=Manetsch|first=Scott M.|title=Calvin's Company of Pastors: Pastoral Care and the Emerging Reformed Church, 1536-1609|year=2013|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|language=English|isbn=9780199938575|page=383}}</ref> The [[Geneva#Protestant_Rome|Reformed Church in Geneva]], in order to ensure confessional orthodoxy, "expected parents to select Reformed godparents."<ref name="Maag2016">{{cite book|last=Maag|first=Karin|title=Lifting Hearts to the Lord: Worship with John Calvin in Sixteenth-Century Geneva|date=13 January 2016|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Company|language=English|isbn=9781467444002|page=162}}</ref> Today, many Reformed churches invite parents to select godparents for their prospective neophyte, while other parishes entrust this responsibility to the whole [[Local church|congregation]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fccucc.org/worship/baptism-communion/|title=Baptism & Communion|last=Maddox|first=Cindy|publisher=First Congregational Church - United Church of Christ|language=English|accessdate=12 August 2017|quote=You’re welcome to invite one or two Godparents to take part in the baptism service, though this is optional and matter of personal choice.}}</ref><ref name="Wehrheim2006">{{cite book|last=Wehrheim|first=Carol A.|title=The Baptism of Your Child: A Book for Presbyterian Families|year=2006|publisher=Westminster John Knox Press|language=English|isbn=9780664502850|page=24}}</ref>
====Roman Catholic Church==== [[File:Baptism at St. Mary's Church in Dedham, Massachusetts.jpg|thumb|A child being baptized with her parents and godparents.]] The Catholic institution of godparenthood survived the Reformation largely unchanged. A godparent must normally be an appropriate person, at least sixteen years of age, a confirmed Catholic who has received the [[Eucharist]], not under any canonical penalty, and may not be the parent of the child. Someone who belongs to another Christian church cannot become a godparent but can be a 'witness' in conjunction with a Catholic sponsor. A witness does not have any religious role recognized by the Church.<ref>''Code of Canon Law'' Can. 872-4 [http://www.vatican.va/archive/ENG1104/__P2Y.HTM].</ref>
In 2015, the Vatican declared that transgender Catholics cannot become godparents, stating in response to a transgender man's query that transgender status "reveals in a public way an attitude opposite to the moral imperative of solving the problem of sexual identity according to the truth of one's own sexuality" and that, "[t]herefore it is evident that this person does not possess the requirement of leading a life according to the faith and in the position of godfather and is therefore unable to be admitted to the position of godfather or godmother."<ref>{{cite web |last=Wofford |first=Taylor |title=Transgender Catholics Can't Be Godparents, Vatican Says|url=http://www.newsweek.com/vatican-transgender-godparents-368142|publisher=Newsweek.com|date=September 2, 2015|accessdate=September 23, 2015}}</ref>
===Spiritual kinship=== {{See also|Compadre}} In some Catholic and Orthodox countries, particularly in southern Europe, Latin America, and the Philippines, the relationship between parents and godparents or co-godparents has been seen as particularly important and distinctive.<ref>G. M. Foster, 'Confradia and compradrazgo in Spain and Spanish America', ''Southwestern Journal of Anthropology'', 9 (1953), pp. 1–3.</ref> These relationships create mutual obligations and responsibilities that may be socially useful for participants. The [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]] ''[[compadre]]'' (literally, "co-father") and ''comadre'' ("co-mother"), the [[French language|French]] ''marraine'' and ''parrain'', and the archaic meaning of the English word ''[[gossip]]'' (from ''godsib,'' "godsibling"), describe these relationships.<ref>W. Coster, ''Baptism and Spiritual Kinship in Early Modern England'' (Ashgate, 2002), pp. 91–7.</ref> By extension, they can also be used to describe a friendship.
The Spanish and Portuguese words for the godparent roles are used for members of the [[wedding party]]—''padrino/padrinho'' meaning "godfather" or "[[best man]]" and ''madrina/madrinha'' meaning "godmother" or "[[matron of honor]]", reflecting the custom of baptismal sponsors acting in this role in a couple's wedding.<ref>H. G. Nutini, and E. Bell, ''Ritual Kinship: The Structure and Historical Development of the Compadrazgo System in Rural Tlaxcala'' 1 (Princeton, 1980), p. 342.</ref>
The Spanish custom was also adopted in the Philippines, a predominantly Christian country in [[Southeast Asia]] that was a former part of the Spanish Empire. The Filipino terms ''ninong'' for godfather and ''ninang'' for godmother, were also borrowed from Hispanic custom, and apply to godparents in both a child's Baptism and the child's later Confirmation. In the context of a wedding, the terms instead refer to the principal sponsors of the couple.
===Literature and folklore=== {{See also|Fairy godmother}} Godparents are noted features of fairy tales and folklore written from the 17th century onwards, and by extension, have found their way into many modern works of fiction. In ''[[Godfather Death]]'', presented by the [[Brothers Grimm]], the archetype is, unusually, a supernatural godfather. However, most are a [[fairy godmother]] as in versions of ''[[Cinderella]]'', ''[[Sleeping Beauty]]'', and ''[[The Blue Bird (fairy tale)|The Blue Bird]]''. This feature may simply reflect the Catholic milieu in which most fairy tales were created, or at least recorded, and the accepted role of godparents as helpers from outside the family, but [[feminist]] [[Marina Warner]] suggests that they may be a form of wish fulfilment by female narrators.<ref>M. Warner, ''From the Beast to the Blonde, on Fairy Tales and Their Tellers'' (London, 1995), pp. 215-6.</ref>
==Non-Christian traditions==
===Santeria=== In the [[Yoruba religion]] [[Santería]], godparents must have completed their santo or their [[Ifá]]. A person gets his Madrina and Yubona (co-godmother) or his Padrino and Yubon (co-godfather). A santero, aside from his co-godparents, may have an oluo (babalawo, initiate of ifa) who consults him with an ekuele (divinating chain).
===Judaism=== [[Image:Nimrod ST 07.JPG|thumb|right|''[[Brit milah]]''—the ''[[sandek]]'' holds the baby boy]] There are two roles in the [[Jewish circumcision]] ceremony that are sometimes translated as ''godparent''. The [[sandek]] holds the baby boy while he is circumcised. Among Orthodox Ashkenazi, the [[Jewish circumcision#Kvatter|kvater]] (or kvaterin if female) is the person who takes the child from his mother and carries him into the room in which the circumcision is performed. Kvater is etymologically derived from the archaic German ''Gevatter'' ("godfather").
===Chinese traditions=== Some Chinese communities practise the custom of matching a child with a relative or family friend who becomes the godmother (乾媽) or godfather (乾爹). This practice is largely non-religious in nature, but commonly done to strengthen ties or to fulfill the wish of a childless adult to have a "son/daughter". In most circumstances, an auspicious day is selected during which a ceremony takes place, involving the godchild paying his/her respects to his new godfather/godmother in the presence of relatives or friends.<ref>D. Waters, [https://web.archive.org/web/20120405095449/http://sunzi.lib.hku.hk/hkjo/view/44/4402012.pdf "Taking a Godson" ], ''Journals of The Royal Asiatic Society Hong Kong Branch'', Vol. 33, 1993.</ref>
Alternatively, as it is already common in Chinese kinship to use kinship terms among people that are not related (e.g. addressing a respected coworker as "brother" or one's father's friend may be referred to as "uncle"), an older friend or family friend with a deep friendship and a sufficient age gap will also informally address the other as his godparent or godchild, a gesture often initiated by the older person.
==See also== {{portal|Christianity|Law}} *[[Catechumen]] *[[Legal guardian]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{EB1911 Poster|Sponsor}} *{{Wiktionary-inline}}
[[Category:Family]] [[Category:Parenting]] [[Category:Baptism]]
