{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Trichoderma'' species}} Currently the '''List of ''Trichoderma'' species''' includes 89 accepted species within the ''[[Trichoderma]]'' genus of [[fungus|fungi]]. ''[[Hypocrea]]'' are [[teleomorph]]s of ''Trichoderma'' which themselves have ''Hypocrea'' as [[anamorphs]].{{cite journal|last=Samuels|first=Gary J.|year=2006|title=Trichoderma: Systematics, the Sexual State, and Ecology|journal=Phytopathology|volume=96|issue=2|pages=195–206|issn=0031-949X|pmid=18943925|doi=10.1094/PHYTO-96-0195|url=http://apsjournals.apsnet.org/doi/abs/10.1094/PHYTO-96-0195}} ''Trichoderma'' species include: {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *''[[Trichoderma aggressivum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma amazonicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma asperellum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma atroviride]]'' *''[[Trichoderma aureoviride]]'' *''[[Trichoderma austrokoningii]]'' *''[[Trichoderma brevicompactum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma candidum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma caribbaeum var. aequatoriale]]'' *''[[Trichoderma caribbaeum var. caribbaeum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma catoptron]]'' *''[[Trichoderma cremeum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma ceramicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma cerinum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma chlorosporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma chromospermum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma cinnamomeum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma citrinoviride]]'' *''[[Trichoderma crassum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma cremeum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma dingleyeae]]'' *''[[Trichoderma dorotheae]]'' *''[[Trichoderma effusum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma erinaceum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma estonicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma fertile]]'' *''[[Trichoderma gelatinosus]]'' *''[[Trichoderma ghanense]]'' *''[[Trichoderma hamatum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma harzianum]]''
[[syn.]] ''Trichoderma narcissi'' Tochinai & Shimada 1930[https://www.jstor.org/stable/3761332 W. Gams and W. Meyer. What Exactly Is ''Trichoderma harzianum''? Mycologia. Vol. 90, No. 5 (Sep. - Oct., 1998), pp. 904-915] *''[[Trichoderma helicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma intricatum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma konilangbra]]'' *''[[Trichoderma koningii]]'' *''[[Trichoderma koningiopsis]]'' *''[[Trichoderma longibrachiatum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma longipile]]'' *''[[Trichoderma minutisporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma oblongisporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma ovalisporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma paucisporum]]''{{cite journal|last1=Samuels|first1=Gary J.|last2=Suarez|first2=Carmen|last3=Solis|first3=Karina|last4=Holmes|first4=Keith A.|last5=Thomas|first5=Sarah E.|last6=Ismaiel|first6=Adnan|last7=Evans|first7=Harry C.|title=Trichoderma theobromicola and T. paucisporum: two new species isolated from cacao in South America|journal=Mycological Research|volume=110|issue=4|year=2006|pages=381–392|issn=0953-7562|doi=10.1016/j.mycres.2006.01.009|pmid=16621496|url=https://naldc.nal.usda.gov/naldc/download.xhtml?id=12224&content=PDF}} *''[[Trichoderma petersenii]]'' *''[[Trichoderma phyllostahydis]]'' *''[[Trichoderma piluliferum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma pleuroticola]]'' *''[[Trichoderma pleurotum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma polysporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma pseudokoningii]]'' *''[[Trichoderma pubescens]]'' *''[[Trichoderma reesei]]'' *''[[Trichoderma rogersonii]]'' *''[[Trichoderma rossicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma saturnisporum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma sinensis]]'' *''[[Trichoderma sinuosum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma songyi]]''{{cite journal |vauthors=Park MS, Oh SY, Cho HJ, Fong JJ, Cheon WJ, Lim YW |title=''Trichoderma songyi'' sp. nov., a new species associated with the pine mushroom (''Tricholoma matsutake'') |journal=Antonie van Leeuwenhoek |year=2014 |volume=106 |issue=4 |pages=593–603 |doi=10.1007/s10482-014-0230-4 |pmid=25052534}} *''[[Trichoderma sp. MA 3642]]'' *''[[Trichoderma sp. PPRI 3559]]'' *''[[Trichoderma spirale]]'' *''[[Trichoderma stramineum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma strigosum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma stromaticum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma surrotundum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma taiwanense]]'' *''[[Trichoderma thailandicum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma thelephoricolum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma theobromicola]]'' *''[[Trichoderma tomentosum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma velutinum]]'' *''[[Trichoderma virens]]'' *''[[Trichoderma virgatum]]''{{cite journal |vauthors=Cserjesi AJ, Johnson EL |title=''Methylation of pentachlorophenol by Trichoderma virgatum.''|journal=Canadian Journal of Microbiology |year=1972 |volume=18 |pages=45–49 |doi=10.1139/m72-007}} *''[[Trichoderma viride]]'' *''[[Trichoderma viridescens]]'' {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Wikispecies inline|Trichoderma|''Trichoderma''}} *{{Commonscat inline|Trichoderma|''Trichoderma''}} [[Category:Trichoderma| ]] [[Category:Lists of fungal species|Trichoderma]]

page.title: List of national parks of France

revision.comment: added [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in France]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[Image:Parcs naturels français.svg|thumb|300px|French national parks (in red), [[Regional natural parks of France|regional parks]] (in green) and marine parks (in blue)]] The national parks of France is a system of ten [[national park]]s throughout metropolitan [[France]] and its [[overseas department]]s, coordinated by the government agency Parcs Nationaux de France. The first national park was established in 1963 and the most recent park was created in 2012. The French national parks protect a total area of {{convert|3,710|km2|mi2}} in core area and {{convert|9,162|km2|mi2}} in buffer zones in metropolitan France. This puts over 2% of the total area of metropolitan France under some level of protection. French national parks draw over seven million visitors every year. ==List== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !Name !class="unsortable"|Photography !Department !Area !Established |- | [[Vanoise National Park]]

|[[Mukōjima-Hyakkaen Garden]]||[[Sumida, Tokyo|Sumida]]||1939||8,718|| |- |[[Ōkuma Garden]]||[[Shinjuku, Tokyo|Shinjuku]]|| ||'''3,000'''|| |- |[[Ōi Futō Chūō Kaihin Park]]||[[Shinagawa]] and [[Ōta, Tokyo|Ōta]]||1978||454,271||Largest park in [[Shinagawa|Shinagawa Ward]] |- |[[Rikugien Garden]]||[[Bunkyō, Tokyo|Bunkyō]]||1938Year donated to city government||87,809|| |- |[[Shakujii Park]]||[[Nerima, Tokyo|Nerima]]||1959||223,785|| |- |Saigōyama Park||[[Meguro]]||1981||10,549||Largest park wholly in [[Meguro|Meguro Ward]] |- |[[Shin-Edogawa Garden]]||[[Bunkyō, Tokyo|Bunkyō]]||1961||'''500'''|| |- |[[Shinjuku Central Park]]||[[Shinjuku]]||1968||88,065|| |- |[[Shinjuku Gyoen]]||[[Shinjuku]] and [[Shibuya]]||1949||583,000||Largest park in [[Shinjuku|Shinjuku Ward]] |- |[[Showa Memorial Park]]||[[Tachikawa]]||1983||1,653,000||Largest park in Tokyo Prefecture |- |[[Sumida Park]]||[[Sumida, Tokyo|Sumida]] and [[Taitō]]||1931||'''107,797'''|| |- |[[Tetsugaku-dō Park]]||[[Nakano, Tokyo|Nakano]] and [[Shinjuku]]||1904||52,494|| |- |[[Toneri Park]]||[[Adachi, Tokyo|Adachi]]||1940||628,603||Largest park in [[Adachi, Tokyo|Adachi Ward]] |- |[[Tonogayato Garden]]||[[Kokubunji, Tokyo|Kokubunji]]||1979||21,124 || |- |[[Ueno Park]]||[[Taitō]]||1873||538,506||Largest park in [[Taitō|Taitō Ward]] |- |[[Yokoamicho Park]]||[[Sumida, Tokyo|Sumida]]||1930||195,780|| |- |[[Yoyogi Park]]||[[Shibuya, Tokyo|Shibuya]]||1967||541,000||Largest park in [[Shibuya|Shibuya Ward]] |- |[[Yumenoshima Park]]||[[Koto, Tokyo|Kōtō]]||1978||433,212||Largest park in [[Koto, Tokyo|Kōtō Ward]] |} Note: Figures in '''bold''' are approximate values. ==Flowers== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Type of flower ! Blooming season ! Locations |- |[[Ume]] blossoms||February–March||[[Yoshino Baigo]] in Ome, [[Mukōjima-Hyakkaen Garden]], Hanegi Park in Umegaoka |- |[[Sakura|Cherry blossoms]] (''sakura'')||Late March – early April||[[Ueno Park]] and [[Shinobazu Pond]], [[Yoyogi Park]], [[Shinjuku Gyoen]], [[Inokashira Park]] in Kichijōji, [[Chidorigafuchi]] Imperial Palace moat near the [[Nippon Budokan|Budokan]], [[Meguro River]], [[Aoyama Cemetery]], Sumida Park and River near Asakusa, [[International Christian University]] |- |[[Wisteria]]||Late April – early May||[[Kameido Tenjin Shrine]] in Kōtō Ward |- |[[Azaleas]]||Late April – early May||[[Nezu Shrine]], [[East Garden of the Imperial Palace]], Shiofune Kannon Temple in Ome |- |[[Rose]]s||mid – late May||Jindai Botanical Garden in Chōfu |- |[[Iris (plant)|Irises]]||early – mid June||[[Meiji Shrine]], [[Horikiri Iris Garden]] |- |[[Hydrangeas]]||June–July||Takahata Fudo Temple, Hino |} ==National parks== [[Image:Fujisan from Motohakone.jpg|thumb|right|[[Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park]]]] There are four national parks in Tokyo Prefecture: * [[Chichibu Tama Kai National Park]], in Nishitama and spilling over into [[Yamanashi Prefecture|Yamanashi]] and [[Saitama Prefecture|Saitama]] Prefectures * [[Meiji no Mori Takao Quasi-National Park]], around [[Mount Takao]] to the south of Hachioji. * [[Fuji-Hakone-Izu National Park]], which includes all of the Izu Islands. * [[Ogasawara Islands|Ogasawara National Park]]. [[Wikipedia:As of|As of]] 2006, efforts were being made to make Ogasawara National Park a [[UNESCO]] natural [[World Heritage Site]]. ==Notes== {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commonscat-inline|Parks in Tokyo}} [[Category:Gardens in Tokyo| ]] [[Category:Parks and gardens in Tokyo| ]] [[Category:Lists of parks|Tokyo]] [[Category:Lists of gardens|Tokyo]] [[Category:Lists of tourist attractions in Japan]]

page.title: List of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2014

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}}
{{Use American English|date=May 2016}} The following is a '''list of pipeline accidents in the United States in 2014'''. It is one of several [[list of pipeline accidents in the United States|lists of U.S. pipeline accidents]]. See also [[list of natural gas and oil production accidents in the United States]]. {{expand list|date=April 2013}} __NOTOC__ <!--begin temporary compact toc--> <!-- something nicer-looking and more navigable should be done here; this is a temporary TOC to ease navigation --> <!-- | bgcolor=#dddddd align=center colspan=11 | See also – [[#References|References]] --> <!--end compact toc-->
This is not a complete list of all pipeline accidents. '''For natural gas alone''', the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA), a United States Department of Transportation agency, has collected data on more than 3,200 accidents deemed serious or significant since 1987.
A "significant incident" results in any of the following consequences: * fatality or injury requiring in-patient hospitalization * $50,000 or more in total costs, measured in 1984 dollars * liquid releases of five or more barrels (42 US gal/barrel) * releases resulting in an unintentional fire or explosion
PHMSA and the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) post incident data and results of investigations into accidents involving pipelines that carry a variety of products, including natural gas, oil, diesel fuel, gasoline, kerosene, jet fuel, carbon dioxide, and other substances. Occasionally pipelines are repurposed to carry different products.<ref>Data sets of PHMSA Pipeline Safety-Flagged Incidents for 1986-2001, 2002-2009, and 2010-2017 can be downloaded from the tab by that name on the PHMSA's Pipeline Incident Flagged Files page at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/data-and-statistics/pipeline/pipeline-incident-flagged-files, accessed 2018.01.10. PHMSA Corrective Action Orders are at https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/CAO_opid_0.html. PHMSA Pipeline Failure Investigation Reports are at https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/safety-reports/pipeline-failure-investigation-reports. NTSB Pipeline Accident Reports are at https://www.ntsb.gov/investigations/AccidentReports/Pages/pipeline.aspx.</ref>
== Incidents == * On January 7, a [[Colonial Pipeline]] line leak resulted from equipment failure in [[Fountain Inn, South Carolina]], spilling about 52,000 gallons of petroleum product, of which around 8,000 gallons was not recovered.<ref name="dot5">{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343#_Incidents_tab_3 |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |author= |date= |work=dot.gov |accessdate=May 23, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307113746/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_2552.html?nocache=7343 |archivedate=March 7, 2016 }}</ref> * On January 10, a 12-inch PSNC gas transmission pipeline exploded and burned in [[Asheville, North Carolina]]. The cause was damage to the pipeline during installation in 2003. There were no injuries, but the costs of property damage was around $825,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.citizen-times.com/article/20140211/NEWS01/302110026/Asheville-gas-line-explosion-cost-825-000?nclick_check=1|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140213195836/http://www.citizen-times.com/article/20140211/NEWS01/302110026/Asheville-gas-line-explosion-cost-825-000?nclick_check=1|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 13, 2014|title=Ashevill gas line explosion costs $825,000|work=The Asheville Citizen-Times|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * On January 29, about 600 people were evacauted from their homes & businesses, after the gas distribution system were over pressurized, in [[Lansing, Michigan]]. * On February 10, a gas pipeline exploded and burned near [[Tioga, North Dakota]]. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greenfieldreporter.com/view/story/9f9d80ef83364d64818f3134913f172a/ND--Tioga-Gas-Explosion |title=Archived copy |accessdate=February 13, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222133632/http://www.greenfieldreporter.com/view/story/9f9d80ef83364d64818f3134913f172a/ND--Tioga-Gas-Explosion |archivedate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> * On February 13, a 30-inch diameter Columbia Gulf Transmission gas pipeline carrying natural gas exploded near [[Knifley, Kentucky]], sending two people to the hospital with injuries, destroying two houses, and alarming residents, who saw flames from miles away. Later, it was determined that [[Hydrogen embrittlement]] had caused the pipe failure from when the pipeline was installed in 1965.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/26571543/analysis-existing-cracks-a-cause-in-kentucky-pipeline-blast |date=September 18, 2014 |publisher=WorldNow and WDRB |title=Analysis: Existing cracks a cause in Kentucky pipeline blast |author=Marcus Green |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140920210310/http://www.wdrb.com/story/26571543/analysis-existing-cracks-a-cause-in-kentucky-pipeline-blast |archivedate=September 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Ky. gas line blast injures 2, destroys 2 homes |url=http://www.kansas.com/2014/02/13/3286103/ky-gas-line-blast-hospitalizes.html |accessdate=October 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222031345/http://www.kansas.com/2014/02/13/3286103/ky-gas-line-blast-hospitalizes.html |archivedate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> * On February 19, a leaking gas main caused a gas build up in a nearby rowhouse, that exploded in [Baltimore, Maryland], killing one youth, and seriously injuring another walking by the area. 3 other people had minor injuries. The area on the gas main near the leak had been patched twice in previous months.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.naturalgaswatch.org/?p=2909 |title=Boy killed as house collapsed was planning to attend birthday party - Natural Gas Watch.org |work=naturalgaswatch.org |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160806225622/http://www.naturalgaswatch.org/?p=2909# |archivedate=August 6, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2016/05/28/rene-marsh-aging-pipelines.cnn |title=America's aging pipelines – CNN Video |work=cnn.com |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916070015/http://www.cnn.com/videos/politics/2016/05/28/rene-marsh-aging-pipelines.cnn |archivedate=September 16, 2016 }}</ref> * On March 6, contractors working for [[Shell Oil Company]] hit Shell's Houston-to-Houma (Ho-Ho) crude oil pipeline near [[Port Neches, Texas]], spilling 364 barrels of crude oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bayoubuzz.com/top-stories/item/623940-shell-says-ho-ho-pipeline-shut-after-leak-in-texas |title=Archived copy |accessdate=March 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140310083055/http://www.bayoubuzz.com/top-stories/item/623940-shell-says-ho-ho-pipeline-shut-after-leak-in-texas |archivedate=March 10, 2014}}</ref> * '''[[2014 East Harlem gas explosion]]''': On March 12, there was a gas explosion in [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. NTSB investigators found natural gas in the soil nearby, indicating that the gas leak had existed for a while before the explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2014/03/14/firefighters-continue-search-for-missing-at-east-harlem-blast-site/ |title=NTSB: Abnormal Concentration Of Gas Found Near East Harlem Blast Scene |publisher=CBS New York |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141026110131/http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2014/03/14/firefighters-continue-search-for-missing-at-east-harlem-blast-site/ |archivedate=October 26, 2014 }}</ref> * On March 17, a 20-inch Mid-Valley Pipeline Company pipeline failed in [[Hamilton County, Ohio]], spilling about 18,900 gallons of crude oil into an adjacent wildlife preserve. Animals in the area were affected. The cause was environmental cracking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wlwt.com/news/oil-spill-cleanup-ending-20-salamanders-being-cared-for-offsite/25314396 |title=Oil spill cleanup ending; 20 salamanders being cared for off-site |work=WLWT.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020114846/http://www.wlwt.com/news/oil-spill-cleanup-ending-20-salamanders-being-cared-for-offsite/25314396 |archivedate=October 20, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2014-5002H |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320145002H/320145002H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03252014_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161221122258/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320145002H/320145002H_Corrective%20Action%20Order_03252014_text.pdf |archivedate=December 21, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="dot.gov1">{{cite web|url=https://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorIM_opid_12470.html?nocache=4784#_Incidents_tab_3|title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications - Operator Information|website=primis.phmsa.dot.gov}}</ref> * On March 18, a 3-inch, half-mile flare waste gas pipeline in a neighborhood in [[Arvin, California]], was discovered leaking, a few blocks from Arvin High School, in a residential area. It had been leaking for as long as two years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bakersfieldcalifornian.com/local/x588887534/Arvin-still-in-the-dark-about-leaking-gas-line |title=Arvin still in the dark about leaking gas line |work=The Bakersfield Californian |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023135500/http://www.bakersfieldcalifornian.com/local/x588887534/Arvin-still-in-the-dark-about-leaking-gas-line |archivedate=October 23, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> * On March 31, a pipeline running to a [[Williams Companies]] LNG storage facility in [[Plymouth, Washington]] exploded and sent shrapnel flying that ruptured an LNG storage tank. Nearly 1,000 residents were evacuated and at least five employees at the facility were injured.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/03/31/3421102/massive-explosion-natural-gas-plant/ |title=Massive Explosion Rocks Washington State Natural Gas Plant |publisher=thinkprogress.com |date=March 31, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114230930/http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2014/03/31/3421102/massive-explosion-natural-gas-plant/ |archivedate=January 14, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://co.williams.com/williams/news-media/plymouth-wa-update/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=June 23, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701204335/http://co.williams.com/williams/news-media/plymouth-wa-update/ |archivedate=July 1, 2014}}</ref> * A 12-inch [[Williams Companies]] gas pipeline failed at a weld in [[Moundsville, West Virginia]]. The following explosion and fire explosion scorched trees over a 2-acre area near Moundsville. Several houses were evacuated as a precaution. There were no injuries reported.<ref>{{cite web|title=Company won't be cited for W.Va. pipeline blast |url=http://www.theintermountain.com/page/content.detail/id/493996/Company-won-t-be-cited-for-W-Va--pipeline-blast.html?isap=1&nav=5023 |accessdate=October 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140517130357/http://www.theintermountain.com/page/content.detail/id/493996/Company-won-t-be-cited-for-W-Va--pipeline-blast.html?isap=1&nav=5023 |archivedate=May 17, 2014 |df= }}</ref> * On April 17, a private excavator accidentally cut a gas line while doing some work in [[Union Township, Licking County, Ohio]] on April 17. The man suffered second degree burns to the upper portion of his body. There was no damage to any buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newarkadvocate.com/article/20140417/NEWS01/304170014/Natural-gas-line-ruptures-Union-Township-man-taken-hospital |title=Natural gas line ruptures in Union Township; man taken to hospital |work=The Newark Advocate |date=April 17, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006083948/http://www.newarkadvocate.com/article/20140417/NEWS01/304170014/Natural-gas-line-ruptures-Union-Township-man-taken-hospital |archivedate=October 6, 2014}}</ref> * On April 23, an explosion and fire hit a [[Williams Companies]] gas processing plant in [[Opal, Wyoming]]. All 95 residents of the town were evacuated, and part of US Highway 30 was closed for a time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.localnews8.com/news/explosion-and-fire-force-evacuation-of-town/25627492 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=May 15, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517122251/http://www.localnews8.com/news/explosion-and-fire-force-evacuation-of-town/25627492 |archivedate=May 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/fire-still-burns-at-damaged-wyoming-gas-plant/article_67b11cdf-0b76-53b9-8050-a2504d3e2e3d.html |title=Fire still burns at damaged Wyoming gas plant |agency=Associated Press |work=Casper Star-Tribune Online |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016114009/http://trib.com/news/state-and-regional/fire-still-burns-at-damaged-wyoming-gas-plant/article_67b11cdf-0b76-53b9-8050-a2504d3e2e3d.html |archivedate=October 16, 2014 }}</ref> * On May 6, [[Sinclair Oil Corporation]] pipeline operators detected a pressure drop on a pipeline, with the problem being traced two days later to a leak in [[Knox County, Missouri]]. A mixture of gasoline and diesel fuel contaminated soil on a farm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nemonews.net/2014/05/08/pipeline-rupture-hazardous-material-spill-knox/ |title=Pipeline Rupture, Hazardous Material Spill in Knox |work=nemonews.net |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021071252/http://nemonews.net/2014/05/08/pipeline-rupture-hazardous-material-spill-knox/ |archivedate=October 21, 2014 }}</ref> * On May 12, three workers from [[Plantation Pipeline]] inadvertently ruptured their pipeline at a pump station in [[Anderson County, South Carolina]], causing a geyser of gasoline, and spraying the workers with it. There was no fire, but the workers had to be decontaminated at a hospital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wyff4.com/news/natural-gas-line-ruptures-in-anderson-county/25935562 |title=Gas line ruptures, 150-foot geyser of gas spews onto workers |work=WYFF4 |date=May 13, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717072505/http://www.wyff4.com/news/natural-gas-line-ruptures-in-anderson-county/25935562 |archivedate=July 17, 2014 }}</ref> * On May 17, at [[Port St. John, Florida]], Kinder Morgan's 36" Florida Gas Transmission pipeline ruptured, forcing evacuation of seven homes and halting train traffic through Brevard Co. for three hours near the Florida Power & Light plant. Florida Gas Transmission workers searched for a leak when pressure dropped in the line. Homes, vehicle and train traffic were reopened after the remaining gas escaped from the pipe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/story/news/local/2014/05/17/gas-leak-prompts-evacuations-in-north-cocoa/9210351/,|title=Port St. John gas line rupture under investigation|publisher=}}</ref> This pipeline failure caused $177,321 in property damage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/Operatorlist.html#. |title=PHMSA: Stakeholder Communications – Operator Information |website=Primis.phmsa.dot.gov |accessdate=January 19, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128103932/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/operator/OperatorList.html |archivedate=January 28, 2016 }}</ref> * On June 26, near [[East Bernard, Texas]], a gas pipeline adjacent to a [[Kinder Morgan]] gas compressor plant blew out, destroying the roadway and setting a nearby truck on fire just south of Highway 59. Flames as high as 150 feet were shooting out of the pipeline. The focus was on a 27-inch pipeline that sends gasoline to different tank farms along the line.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abc13.com/news/gas-line-explosion-sends-150-foot-flames-up-in-air/142620/ |title=Wharton County gas line explosion sends 150-foot flames up in air |work=ABC13 Houston |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |date=May 13, 2014 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006072131/http://abc13.com/news/gas-line-explosion-sends-150-foot-flames-up-in-air/142620/ |archivedate=October 6, 2014 }}</ref> * On July 10, a vent stack at a Williams Field Services gas pipeline compressor station in [[Susquehanna County, Pennsylvania]] caught fire. Only minor damage was reported at other parts of the station.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://golackawanna.com/news/local-news-news/1523876/Susquehanna-County-compressor-station-shut-down-after-morning-fire#.U-Xv7aNQjTo |title=Susquehanna County compressor station shut down after morning fire |author= |work=Times Leader |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |date=July 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021154242/http://golackawanna.com/news/local-news-news/1523876/Susquehanna-County-compressor-station-shut-down-after-morning-fire |archivedate=October 21, 2014}}</ref> * On July 23, in [[Milledgeville, Georgia]], Midway Elementary School faculty and staff were evacuated due to a fire, caused by a gas leak at nearby Southern Natural Gas Co. tap station. Fire rescue personnel closed down Highway 441 South for an hour. Due to the amount of pressure, precautionary measures were taken so pipe wouldn't rupture under the road while Southern Natural Gas tried to determine the cause of the leak. "It could be some type of failure in a valve or regulator. Right now we don't know but Southern Natural Gas is looking into it." No injuries were reported.<ref>Felicia Cummings, "Gas leak near Midway Elementary," The Union-Recorder, July 23, 2014 4:15 pm | Updated: August 7, 2014.</ref> * On August 4, a Greka 6 inch pipeline spilled over 1,200 gallons of crude oil at the Zick Compressor Station by Williams Field Services in Hop Bottom near [[Santa Barbara County, California]]. The oil spread out over less than a mile from the leak and did not enter a river. The station can process 455 million cubic feet of natural gas per day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ksby.com/news/update-crews-contain-oil-spill-near-santa-maria/ |title=Crews contain oil spill near Santa Maria |work=KSBY.com |date=August 4, 2014 |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205054839/http://www.ksby.com/news/update-crews-contain-oil-spill-near-santa-maria/ |archivedate=February 5, 2015}}</ref> * On August 12, a mulching machine hit a 12-inch natural gas pipeline in [[Rusk County, Texas]]. The operator of the machine was killed in the following explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ketknbc.com/news/one-man-killed-in-natural-gas-pipeline-explosion-i |title=White Oak man killed in Rusk Co. pipeline explosion |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150222125425/http://www.ketknbc.com/news/one-man-killed-in-natural-gas-pipeline-explosion-i |archivedate=February 22, 2015}}</ref> * On August 20, a Buckeye Partners pipeline leaked, inside their terminal, in [[Linden, New Jersey]]. About 5900 gallons of jet fuel were spilled, of which most was recovered. The cause of the leak was from internal corrosion of the line.<ref>[https://www.phmsa.dot.gov/staticfiles//PHMSA/DownloadableFiles/Files/Pipeline/Failure%20Reports/147585_Buckeye_Linden_Failure_Investigation_Report_2014_08_20.pdf]{{dead link|date=February 2018}}</ref> * On August 21, four workers were injured in a fire while a crew was performing maintenance on a natural gas pipeline in [[Garvin County, Oklahoma]]. The injured workers were treated and released from a hospital, and there was no explosion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/business/energy/four-hurt-after-natural-gas-line-catches-fire-near-lindsay/article_09948ed6-442c-5451-b266-c1041e0ae427.html|title=Four hurt after natural gas line catches fire near Lindsay|work=Tulsa World|accessdate=January 15, 2015}}</ref> * On September 14, a contract worker performing routine maintenance on a [[Chevron Corporation|Chevron]] offshore gas pipeline was killed, and two other workers were injured. The accident occurred 6 miles south of [[Timbalier Bay]] off the southeast coast of Louisiana.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/chevron-worker-dies-in-gulf-of-mexico-pipeline-accident-1410709059 |title=Chevron Shuts Gas Pipeline After Worker Dies in Gulf of Mexico Accident – WSJ |author=Lynn Cook |date=September 15, 2014 |work=WSJ |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140919073950/http://online.wsj.com/articles/chevron-worker-dies-in-gulf-of-mexico-pipeline-accident-1410709059 |archivedate=September 19, 2014 }}</ref> * On September 16, more than 500 residents of [[Benton Charter Township, Michigan|Benton Township, Michigan]], were forced to leave their houses for 10 to 12 hours, after authorities discovered a leak on TransCanada Corporation's 22-inch [[ANR Pipeline|ANR]] gas transmission pipeline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/09/17/transcanada-pipeline-benton-harbor_n_5837862.html |title=TransCanada Pipeline Rupture Prompts Evacuation Of Benton Harbor |work=The Huffington Post |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140921013637/http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/09/17/transcanada-pipeline-benton-harbor_n_5837862.html |archivedate=September 21, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wsbt.com/news/local/transcanada-after-pipeline-rupture-repairs-may-take-several-weeks/28150584 |title=TransCanada: After pipeline rupture, repairs may take several weeks |author= |work=wsbt.com |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112012303/http://www.wsbt.com/news/local/transcanada-after-pipeline-rupture-repairs-may-take-several-weeks/28150584 |archivedate=November 12, 2014 }}</ref> * On September 17, 3 LG&E subcontractors were injured, when a gas main exploded after being hit by equipment during maintenance of the gas main, along a stretch of U.S. 42 in [[Oldham County, Kentucky]]. There was no fire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wave3.com/story/26560231/pipeline-explosion-closes-us-42-in-oldham-county|title=3 LG&E subcontractors injured in gas main explosion on U.S. 42|first=Charles|last=Gazaway|publisher=}}</ref> * On October 13, a gas transmission pipeline failed near [[Centerview, Missouri]], causing an explosion and massive fire for several hours. There were no injuries.<ref name="dot3">{{cite web|title=CPF No. 3-2014-10088 |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150115105300/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/320141008S/320141008S_Notice%20of%20Proposed%20Safety%20Order_12242014.pdf |archivedate=January 15, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kctv5.com/story/26772356/emergency-crews-respond-to-pipeline-rupture-fire-near-centerview#ixzz3G3Gp4Ie3 |title=Emergency crews respond to pipeline rupture, fire near Centervie – KCTV5 |author=Chris Oberholtz |date=October 13, 2014 |work=kctv5.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://www.kctv5.com/story/26772356/emergency-crews-respond-to-pipeline-rupture-fire-near-centerview |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref> * On October 14, a [[Sunoco]]/Mid-Valley crude oil pipeline ruptured, and spilled about 189,000 gallons of crude oil, in [[Caddo Parish, Louisiana]]. Wildlife was killed. The cause of the failure was environmental cracking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/local/2014/10/18/crude-oil-spills-caddo-bayou-kills-wildlife/17522017/ |title=Crude oil spills into Caddo bayou, kills wildlife |author=Vickie Welborn |date=October 18, 2014 |publisher= |accessdate=January 15, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141022001631/http://www.shreveporttimes.com/story/news/local/2014/10/18/crude-oil-spills-caddo-bayou-kills-wildlife/17522017/ |archivedate=October 22, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="dot.gov1"/> * A 24-inch gas transmission pipeline was hit by excavators on October 23, near [[Newport, Arkansas]]. Five nearby houses were evacuated, and two highways and a railroad were closed for a time. There was no fire or injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kait8.com/story/26866351/roads-open-repairs-underway-after-gas-leak |title=Roads open, repairs underway after gas leak |author= |date=October 22, 2014 |work=kait8.com |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202035730/http://www.kait8.com/story/26866351/roads-open-repairs-underway-after-gas-leak |archivedate=February 2, 2016 }}</ref> * On October 28, an 8-inch natural gas condensate pipeline exploded in [[Monroe County, Ohio]]. A large fire followed. There were no injuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/615683/Blue-Racer-Pipeline-Shut-Down-After-Explosion.html?nav=510 |title=Blue Racer Pipeline Shut Down After Explosion |work=The Intelligencer |accessdate=September 16, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304191713/http://www.theintelligencer.net/page/content.detail/id/615683/Blue-Racer-Pipeline-Shut-Down-After-Explosion.html?nav=510 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref> * On December 8, gasoline was discovered leaking from [[Kinder Morgan]] [[Plantation Pipeline]] in [[Belton, South Carolina]]. It was found that the 26-inch pipeline had leaked into a nearby creek. The cause was a failure at a sleeve that was part of an earlier repair.<ref>{{cite web|title=CPF 2-2015-5001S |url=http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220155001S/220155001S_NOPSO_03092015_text.pdf |accessdate=28 November 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161220141445/http://primis.phmsa.dot.gov/comm/reports/enforce/documents/220155001S/220155001S_NOPSO_03092015_text.pdf |archivedate=December 20, 2016 }}</ref> As of April 2015, it was estimated that 369,600 gallons of gasoline had leaked. About 160,500 gallons of gasoline had been recovered and removed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://savannahnow.com/news/2015-04-30/kinder-morgan-pipeline-leak-reaches-300000-gallons-south-carolina |title=Kinder Morgan pipeline leak reaches 300,000 gallons in South Carolina |work=savannahnow.com |accessdate=January 19, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203115900/http://savannahnow.com/news/2015-04-30/kinder-morgan-pipeline-leak-reaches-300000-gallons-south-carolina |archivedate=February 3, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="auto7">{{cite web|url=http://kfgo.com/news/articles/2017/nov/18/top-20-onshore-us-petroleum-spills-since-2010/|title=Top 20 onshore US petroleum spills since 2010|first=Midwest Communications|last=Inc.|website=The Mighty 790 KFGO}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} {{List of pipeline accidents in the United States|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Lists of pipeline accidents in the United States]]

page.title: List of rivers and water bodies of Montreal Island

revision.text:
The '''rivers and water bodies of Montreal''' are few and mostly artificial. Hydrography of the [[island of Montreal]] remained intact until approximately XIXth where [[Montreal]] will undergo major urban works including the construction of [[Lachine Canal]] and the creation of the first [[list of parks in Montreal|major parks of Montreal]].
==History==
===Last Ice Age===
After the [[Ice Age]], around -13 000 years, Montreal and the [[Saint Lawrence Lowlands]] are flooded by the [[Champlain sea]]. Within a few centuries, as and when these waters recede, the [[Mount Royal]] and its three summits are emerged into islands. With the complete withdrawal of the sea, water is retained in some [[Depression (geology)|depression]] of the island. This is the case among other [[Beaver Lake (Montreal)|Beaver Lake]], located in the palm of [[Mount Royal]]. This will dry gradually to become a [[fen]].<ref>[http://www.ledevoir.com/societe/science-et-technologie/408486/le-lac-aux-castors-habite-par-le-rongeur-il-y-a-11-000-ans Article of "journal Le Devoir" - Beaver Lake (Lac aux Castors) on Mount Royal]</ref> He was regrooved artificially in 1938.
===Before XIXth===
[[File:Rivieres de Montreal vers 1700.png|400px|thumbnail|Approximation streams near the fortifications of the city of Montreal in [[New France]]]] There used to be a complex hydrographic, now destroyed or channeled<ref>[http://rivieresperdues.radio-canada.ca/fr/villes/montreal#river4 Radio-Canada]</ref>{{,}}.<ref>[https://sites.google.com/site/indigenecommunity/home/mapping-ecological-indigenous-heritage sites.google.com Carte des sites de l'héritage autochtone]</ref>
* '''[[Lake Otter (Montreal)|Lake Otter]]''' (or '''small lake St. Peter'''): long by about 4 kilometers and one kilometer wide, marshy lake that was halfway between the [[Old Montreal]] and [[Lachine, Quebec|Lachine]], south of Quartier Latin, the [[Saint-Jacques escarpment]], and west of the [[Turcot Interchange]]. It was backfilled and gradually dried up, particularly with the construction of the [[Lachine Canal]] and with the industrialization of the sector. The [[Quebec autoroute 20|highway 20]] runs through the length and breadth of today in the center.<ref>[http://rivieresperdues.radio-canada.ca/fr/villes/montreal/histoire/13 Radio-Canada, emission "Rivières perdues".]</ref> * '''[[Saint-Pierre River (Montreal)|Saint-Pierre River]]''': started in [[Côte-des-Neiges]] down to [[Notre-Dame-de-Grâce]] and widening formed Lake Otter. It then returns to the river and leads to [[St. Lawrence River]] in [[Nuns' Island]]. * '''Little St. Pierre River''': created artificially in 1697 under the name of "St. Gabriel canal". This channel connects the [[Saint-Pierre River (Montreal)|Saint-Pierre River]] (in the east part of [[Lake Otter (Montreal)|Lake Otter]]) up the [[Pointe-à-Callière Museum]]. One part was channeled as qu'égout (William collector) in 1832. The [[Pointe-à-Callière Museum]] would make the public place around 2017.<ref>[http://pacmusee.qc.ca/fr/ a-propos de Pointe-à-Callière museum/museum/future-expansion-museum-projects Article "À propos du musée de Pointe-à-Callière"]</ref> * '''Saint Martin River''' or '''Little River''': It begins at [[Mount Royal Cemetery]] through [[Outremont, Quebec]] and the [[Mile End, Montreal|Mile End]] and [[Plateau Mont-Royal]] until [[La Fontaine Park]] (including the pond is a remnant). Then it branched off westward through the [[Quartier Latin, Montreal|Quartier Latin]] and ran along the [[Montreal fortifications]] to the river. There are still some traces of the river.<ref>[http://gaiapresse.ca/nouvelles/des-rivieres-perdues-un-ruisseau-meconnu-36348.html Article "Des rivières perdues - un ruisseau méconnu"]</ref>
=== Today ===
Today there are only a handful of streams and lakes in nature. However, many parks have ponds or artificial lakes of large size.
== List of water bodies==
Below is a partial list of current waters bodies of the island:

This is a list of [[river]]s, which are at least partially located in [[Germany]]. Rivers that flow into the sea are sorted geographically, along the coast. Rivers that flow into other rivers are sorted by the proximity of their points of confluence to the sea (the lower in the list, the more upstream). Some rivers (e.g. Meuse) do not flow through Germany themselves, but they are mentioned for having German tributaries. They are given in ''italics''. For clarity, only rivers that are longer than {{convert|50|km|mi}} (or have longer tributaries) are shown. An alphabetical list of all German rivers that have an article in Wikipedia is given at the end.
The rivers of Germany flow into the [[Baltic Sea]], the [[Black Sea]] and the [[North Sea]]. The most important rivers of Germany are: *flowing into the Baltic Sea: [[Oder]] *flowing into the Black Sea: [[Danube]] (and its main tributaries [[Inn (river)|Inn]], [[Isar]], and [[Lech (river)|Lech]]) *flowing inside the North Sea: [[Rhine]] (and its main tributaries [[Moselle (river)|Moselle]], [[Main (river)|Main]] and [[Neckar]]), [[Weser]] and [[Elbe]] (and its main tributaries [[Havel]] and [[Saale]])
==Draining into the [[Baltic Sea]]== The rivers in this section are sorted north-west (Danish border) to east (Polish border).
*[[Schwentine]] (in [[Kiel]]) *[[Trave]] (in [[Lübeck]]-[[Travemünde]]) **[[Stepenitz (Trave)|Stepenitz]] (near Travemünde) *[[Warnow]] (in [[Warnemünde]]) **[[Nebel (river)|Nebel]] (in [[Bützow]]) *[[Recknitz]] (in [[Ribnitz-Damgarten]]) *[[Peenestrom]] (in [[Peenemünde]]) **[[Peene]] (near [[Anklam]]) ***[[Tollense]] (in [[Demmin]]) **branch of river [[Oder]] (from [[Oder Lagoon]]) *''[[Świna]]/Swine'' (in [[Świnoujście]], [[Poland]]) **[[Uecker]] (into Oder Lagoon in [[Ueckermünde]]) **[[Oder]] (into Oder Lagoon near [[Szczecin]], Poland) ***[[Lusatian Neisse]] (Lausitzer Neiße) (near [[Eisenhüttenstadt]])

revision.comment: /* Other theories */Various citation & identifier cleanup, plus AWB genfixes (arxiv version pointless when published)
revision.text:
In [[theoretical physics]], a '''mass generation''' mechanism is a theory that describes the origin of [[mass]] from the most fundamental laws of [[physics]]. Physicists have proposed a number of models that advocate different views of the origin of mass. The problem is complicated because the primary role of [[mass]] is to mediate [[gravitational interaction]] between bodies, and no theory of gravitational interaction reconciles with the currently popular [[Standard Model]] of [[particle physics]]. There are two types of mass generation models: gravity-free models and models that involve gravity. ==Background== ===Electroweak theory and the Standard Model=== The [[Higgs mechanism]] is based on a [[spontaneous symmetry breaking|symmetry-breaking]] [[scalar field]] potential, such as the [[Quartic interaction|quartic]]. The Standard Model uses this mechanism as part of the [[Electroweak interaction|Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model]] to unify [[electromagnetism|electromagnetic]] and [[weak interaction|weak]] interactions. This model was one of several that predicted the existence of the scalar [[Higgs boson]]. ==Gravity-free models== In these theories, as in the [[Standard Model]] itself, the [[gravitational interaction]] either is not involved or does not play a crucial role. ===Technicolor=== [[Technicolor (physics)|Technicolor]] models break electroweak symmetry through gauge interactions, which were originally modeled on [[quantum chromodynamics]].{{Citation | author=Steven Weinberg | title=Implications of dynamical symmetry breaking | journal=Physical Review D | volume=13 | date=1976 | pages=974–996 | doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.13.974 | postscript=.|bibcode = 1976PhRvD..13..974W | issue=4 }}
{{Citation | author=S. Weinberg | title=Implications of dynamical symmetry breaking: An addendum | journal=Physical Review D | volume=19 | date=1979 | pages=1277–1280 | doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.19.1277 | postscript=.|bibcode = 1979PhRvD..19.1277W | issue=4 }}{{Citation | author=Leonard Susskind | title=Dynamics of spontaneous symmetry breaking in the Weinberg-Salam theory | journal=Physical Review D| volume=20 | date=1979 | pages=2619–2625 | doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.20.2619 | postscript=.|bibcode = 1979PhRvD..20.2619S | issue=10 }}{{elucidate|date=May 2017}} ===Coleman-Weinberg mechanism=== [[Coleman–Weinberg potential|Coleman–Weinberg mechanism]] generates mass through spontaneous symmetry breaking through [[radiative correction]]s.{{elucidate|date=May 2017}} ===Other theories=== {{prose|date=May 2017}} * [[Unparticle physics]] and the unhiggs{{Cite journal |arxiv = 0807.3961|last1 = Stancato|first1 = David|title = The Unhiggs|journal = JHEP |volume = 0911|issue = 11|pages = 101|last2 = Terning|first2 = John|year = 2009|doi = 10.1088/1126-6708/2009/11/101}}{{Cite journal |arxiv = 0901.3777|last1 = Stancato|first1 = David|title = Electroweak Precision Observables and the Unhiggs|journal = JHEP |volume = 0912|issue = 12|pages = 061|last2 = Terning|first2 = John|year = 2009|doi = 10.1088/1126-6708/2009/12/061}} models posit that the Higgs sector and Higgs boson are scaling invariant, also known as unparticle physics. * UV-Completion by Classicalization, in which the unitarization of the WW scattering happens by creation of classical configurations.{{cite paper |arxiv=1010.1415 |title=UV-Completion by Classicalization |first=Gia |last=Dvali |first2=Gian F. |last2=Giudice |first3=Cesar |last3=Gomez |first4=Alex |last4=Kehagias |year=2011 |bibcode = 2011JHEP...08..108D |doi = 10.1007/JHEP08(2011)108 }} * Symmetry breaking driven by non-equilibrium dynamics of quantum fields above the electroweak scale.{{cite journal | doi = 10.1209/0295-5075/82/11001 | volume=82 | issue=1 | title=Bifurcations and pattern formation in particle physics: An introductory study | journal=EPL | pages=11001|bibcode = 2008EL.....8211001G | last1=Goldfain | first1=E. | year=2008 }}{{cite journal | last1=Goldfain | first1=E. | year=2010 |title=Non-equilibrium Dynamics as Source of Asymmetries in High Energy Physics |journal=Electronic Journal of Theoretical Physics |url=http://www.ejtp.com/articles/ejtpv7i24p219.pdf |volume=7 |issue=24 |pages=219–234}} *Asymptotically safe [[weak interaction]]s {{Citation |first=X. |last=Calmet |date=2011 |title=Asymptotically safe weak interactions|journal= Modern Physics Letters A|volume=26|issue=21 |pages=1571–1576 |arxiv=1012.5529|bibcode = 2011MPLA...26.1571C |doi = 10.1142/S0217732311035900 |citeseerx=10.1.1.757.7245 }}{{Citation |first=X. |last=Calmet |date=2011 |title=An Alternative view on the electroweak interactions|journal= International Journal of Modern Physics A|volume=26|issue=17 |pages=2855–2864 |arxiv=1008.3780|bibcode = 2011IJMPA..26.2855C |doi = 10.1142/S0217751X11053699 |citeseerx=10.1.1.740.5141 }} based on some nonlinear sigma models.{{Citation |first=A. |last=Codello |first2=R. |last2=Percacci |year=2009 |title=Fixed Points of Nonlinear Sigma Models in d>2 |id= |doi=10.1016/j.physletb.2009.01.032 |journal=Physics Letters B |volume=672 |issue=3 |pages=280–283 |arxiv=0810.0715|bibcode = 2009PhLB..672..280C }} * Models of composite W and Z vector bosons.{{citation |first=L. F. |last=Abbott |first2=E. |last2=Farhi |date=1981 |title=Are the Weak Interactions Strong? |journal=[[Physics Letters B]] |volume=101 |issue=1–2 |pages=69 |doi=10.1016/0370-2693(81)90492-5 |bibcode = 1981PhLB..101...69A |citeseerx=10.1.1.362.4721 }} *[[Top quark condensate]]. ==Gravitational models== * [[Extra dimensions|Extra-dimensional]] Higgsless models use the fifth component of the gauge fields in place of the Higgs fields. It is possible to produce electroweak symmetry breaking by imposing certain boundary conditions on the extra dimensional fields, increasing the [[Unitarity (physics)|unitarity]] breakdown scale up to the energy scale of the extra dimension.{{citation |first=C. |last=Csaki |first2=C. |last2=Grojean |first3=L. |last3=Pilo |first4=J. |last4=Terning |date=2004|title=Towards a realistic model of Higgsless electroweak symmetry breaking |journal=[[Physical Review Letters]] |volume=92 |issue=10 |pages=101802 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.92.101802 |id= |pmid=15089195 |arxiv=hep-ph/0308038 |bibcode=2004PhRvL..92j1802C}}{{citation |first=C. |last=Csaki |first2=C. |last2=Grojean |first3=H. |last3=Murayama |first4=L. |last4=Pilo |first5=John |last5=Terning |date=2004 |title=Gauge theories on an interval: Unitarity without a Higgs |journal=[[Physical Review D]] |volume=69 |issue=5 |pages=055006 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.69.055006 |id= |arxiv=hep-ph/0305237|bibcode = 2004PhRvD..69e5006C }} Through the AdS/QCD correspondence this model can be related to technicolor models and to ''UnHiggs'' models, in which the Higgs field is of [[unparticle]] nature.{{Citation |first=X. |last=Calmet |first2=N. G. |last2=Deshpande |first3=X. G. |last3=He |first4=S. D. H. |last4=Hsu |year=2009 |title=Invisible Higgs boson, continuous mass fields and unHiggs mechanism |id= |doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.79.055021 |journal=Physical Review D |volume=79 |issue=5 |pages=055021 |arxiv=0810.2155|bibcode = 2009PhRvD..79e5021C }} * [[Conformal gravity|Unitary Weyl gauge]]. If one adds a suitable gravitational term to the standard model action with gravitational coupling, the theory becomes locally scale-invariant (i.e. Weyl-invariant) in the unitary gauge for the local SU(2). Weyl transformations act multiplicatively on the Higgs field, so one can fix the Weyl gauge by requiring that the Higgs scalar be a constant.{{citation |first=M. |last=Pawlowski |first2=R. |last2=Raczka |date=1994 |title=A Unified Conformal Model for Fundamental Interactions without Dynamical Higgs Field |id= |doi=10.1007/BF02148570 |journal=Foundations of Physics |volume=24 |issue=9 |pages=1305–1327 |arxiv=hep-th/9407137|bibcode = 1994FoPh...24.1305P }} * [[Preon]] and models inspired by preons such as the Ribbon model of [[Standard Model]] particles by [[Sundance Bilson-Thompson]], based in [[braid theory]] and compatible with [[loop quantum gravity]] and similar theories.{{Citation |last=Bilson-Thompson |first=Sundance O. |last2=Markopoulou |first2=Fotini |last3=Smolin |first3=Lee |title=Quantum gravity and the standard model |date=2007 |journal= Classical and Quantum Gravity|volume=24 |issue=16 |pages=3975–3993 |doi=10.1088/0264-9381/24/16/002 |id= |postscript=. |arxiv=hep-th/0603022|bibcode = 2007CQGra..24.3975B }} This model not only explains the origin of mass, but also interprets electric charge as a topological quantity (twists carried on the individual ribbons), and colour charge as modes of twisting. * In the theory of [[superfluid vacuum]], masses of elementary particles arise from interaction with a physical [[vacuum]], similarly to the gap generation mechanism in [[superfluid]]s.{{Cite journal |arxiv = 1108.0847|last1 = Stancato|first1 = David|title = Quantum Bose liquids with logarithmic nonlinearity: Self-sustainability and emergence of spatial extent|journal = Journal of Physics B |volume = 44|issue = 19|pages = 195303|last2 = Terning|first2 = John|year = 2011|doi = 10.1088/0953-4075/44/19/195303}} The low-energy limit of this theory suggests an effective potential for the Higgs sector that is different from the Standard Model's, yet it yields the mass generation.{{Cite journal |arxiv = 0912.4139|last1 = Stancato|first1 = David|title = Spontaneous symmetry breaking and mass generation as built-in phenomena in logarithmic nonlinear quantum theory|journal = Acta Physica Polonica B|volume = 42|issue = 2|pages = 261–292|last2 = Terning|first2 = John|year = 2011|doi = 10.5506/APhysPolB.42.261}}{{Cite journal |arxiv = 1204.6380|last1 = Stancato|first1 = David|title = Singularity-free model of electric charge in physical vacuum: Non-zero spatial extent and mass generation|journal = Open Physics|volume = 11|issue = 3|pages = 325–335|last2 = Terning|first2 = John|year = 2013|doi = 10.2478/s11534-012-0159-z}} Under certain conditions, this potential gives rise to an elementary particle with a role and characteristics similar to the [[Higgs boson]]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Particle physics]] [[Category:Mass]]

revision.comment: /* Lactation */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Science of The Total Environment → Science of the Total Environment
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
In [[aquatic mammal]]s, '''maternal transfer''' is the movement of contaminants from mother to offspring, typically of lipophilic contaminants while in utero or through the mother’s milk. This has become important with the increase in usage of persistent organic pollutants ([[Persistent organic pollutant|POPs]]). POPs [[Biomagnification|biomagnify]] due to their lipophilic nature and become accumulated in the lipid tissues of aquatic mammals. These lipids are used as energy for the mother during the development of offspring, which releases the [[Persistent organic pollutant|POPs]] into the circulatory fluid. This leads to a transfer of the [[toxicant]]s into the developing embryos during gestation as well as into milk that an aquatic mammal produces during lactation.
== History and background == Marine mammals are exposed to a variety of chemicals throughout their life, mostly through their diet. Once the chemicals are accumulated in the body tissues of the mammals, a portion of these chemicals in the female mammals are transferred to their offspring during gestation and lactation.
The degree of maternal-fetal transfer of chemical pollutants is affected by chemical and physical properties of those compounds. [[Lipophilicity]], protein binding, and active transport mechanisms all influence the absorption and distribution of such chemicals in maternal tissues.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aylward|first=L. L.|last2=Hays|first2=S. M.|last3=Kirman|first3=C. R.|last4=Marchitti|first4=S. A.|last5=Kenneke|first5=J. F.|last6=English|first6=C.|last7=Mattison|first7=D. R.|last8=Becker|first8=R. A.|date=2014-01-01|title=Relationships of chemical concentrations in maternal and cord blood: a review of available data|journal=Journal of Toxicology and Environmental Health. Part B, Critical Reviews|volume=17|issue=3|pages=175–203|doi=10.1080/10937404.2014.884956|issn=1521-6950|pmid=24749481}}</ref> Lipophilic chemicals, such as many [[Persistent organic pollutant|POPs]], can be transferred through the fatty portion of milk, while hydrophilic components can be transferred along with the liquid portion of the milk. The placenta provides a barrier to some contaminants, but is partially permeable to others, including many organics and certain heavy metals such as [[lead]], [[Mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[cadmium]], particularly when combined with organic molecules.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kiDfCQAAQBAJ|title=Ecotoxicology Essentials: Environmental Contaminants and Their Biological Effects on Animals and Plants|last=Sparling|first=Donald W.|date=2016-04-18|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=9780128019610|language=en}}</ref>
== Mechanisms of Maternal Transfer ==
=== Lactation === The transfer of contaminants from mother to pup through [[lactation]] is most likely the largest mass transfer of contaminants, greater than that of in-utero transfers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Addison|first=R. F.|last2=Brodie|first2=P. F.|date=1977-07-01|title=Organochlorine Residues in Maternal Blubber, Milk, and Pup Blubber from Grey Seals (Halichoerus grypus) from Sable Island, Nova Scotia|url=http://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/abs/10.1139/f77-146|journal=Journal of the Fisheries Research Board of Canada|volume=34|issue=7|pages=937–941|doi=10.1139/f77-146|issn=0015-296X}}</ref> When the mother begins lactation, blubber lipids are converted into milk lipids to feed her offspring. During this process, toxicants that were stored in [[blubber]] lipids are moved into the milk and subsequently are transferred to the nursing pup.
The transfer of toxicants through lactation is driven by the log Kow of the toxicants. Chemical compounds with a high affinity for lipids (a higher log Kow) will more readily be transferred through lactation due to the high lipid content of milk.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frouin|first=Héloïse|last2=Lebeuf|first2=Michel|last3=Hammill|first3=Mike|last4=Fournier|first4=Michel|date=2012-02-15|title=Transfer of PBDEs and chlorinated POPs from mother to pup during lactation in harp seals Phoca groenlandica|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0048969711014021|journal=Science of the Total Environment|volume=417–418|pages=98–107|doi=10.1016/j.scitotenv.2011.11.084}}</ref> The transfer of toxicants from blubber to milk is not fully understood, and selective transfer of contaminants has been observed.
Mass balance of toxicants is difficult during lactation due to milk lipids originating from blubber lipids as well as being synthesized locally in mammary tissue. The change in toxicant [[solubility]] between blubber and circulatory fluid as well as the breakdown and resynthesis of blubber lipids and circulatory lipids also contributes to the difficulties of mass balance of toxicants between blubber, circulatory, and milk lipids.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Addison|first=R. F.|last2=Brodie|first2=P. F.|date=1987-04-01|title=Transfer of Organochlorine Residues from Blubber through the Circulatory System to Milk in the Lactating Grey Seal Halichoerus grypus|url=http://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/abs/10.1139/f87-095|journal=Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences|volume=44|issue=4|pages=782–786|doi=10.1139/f87-095|issn=0706-652X}}</ref>
However, even with difficulties of mass balancing, it has generally been observed in grey seals and harbor porpoises that residues in pup blubber lipids are generally similar or slightly higher than in maternal milk lipids, and are approximately half of the residues in maternal blubber lipids.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heppleston|first=P. B.|date=1973-03-01|title=Organochlorines in British grey seals|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0025326X73903056|journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin|volume=4|issue=3|pages=44–45|doi=10.1016/0025-326X(73)90305-6}}</ref>
=== Placental Transfer === The transfer of POPs from mother to fetus via the [[placenta]] is less than that of lactation but can still cause adverse effects.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ren|first=Aiguo|last2=Qiu|first2=Xinghua|last3=Jin|first3=Lei|last4=Ma|first4=Jin|last5=Li|first5=Zhiwen|last6=Zhang|first6=Le|last7=Zhu|first7=Huiping|last8=Finnell|first8=Richard H.|last9=Zhu|first9=Tong|date=2011-08-02|title=Association of selected persistent organic pollutants in the placenta with the risk of neural tube defects|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/31/12770|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=108|issue=31|pages=12770–12775|doi=10.1073/pnas.1105209108|issn=0027-8424|pmc=3150927|pmid=21768370}}</ref> Fatty acids from the mother’s plasma are transported either through diffusion or active transport through the placenta to be used in important processes such as brain development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lager|first=Susanne|last2=Powell|first2=Theresa|date=2012|title=Regulation of Nutrient Transport across the Placenta|url=http://www.hindawi.com/journals/jp/2012/179827/|journal=Journal of Pregnancy|doi=10.1155/2012/179827|pmid=|access-date=2016-05-22}}</ref> Sources of fatty acids are mainly derived from blubber in seals, porpoises, and whales.
Lipophilic chemicals such as PCBs previously stored within the mother’s fatty tissue can be transferred to the fetus via the circulatory fluid. Some lipophilic chemicals can be metabolized by the fetus using mostly [[Cytochrome P450|CYP enzymes]], but others are quickly incorporated into developing fetal adipose tissue.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prouillac|first=Caroline|last2=Lecoeur|first2=Sylvaine|date=2010-10-01|title=The role of the placenta in fetal exposure to xenobiotics: importance of membrane transporters and human models for transfer studies|journal=Drug Metabolism and Disposition|volume=38|issue=10|pages=1623–1635|doi=10.1124/dmd.110.033571|issn=1521-009X|pmid=20606001}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Szabo|first=AndrewJ.|last2=Szabo|first2=Olga|date=1974-08-31|title=Originally published as Volume 2, Issue 7879PLACENTAL FREE-FATTY-ACID TRANSFER AND FETAL ADIPOSE-TISSUE DEVELOPMENT: AN EXPLANATION OF FETAL ADIPOSITY IN INFANTS OF DIABETIC MOTHERS|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0140673674920200|journal=The Lancet|volume=304|issue=7879|pages=498–499|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(74)92020-0}}</ref> The storage and release of these chemicals within the fetus can lead to [[Endocrine disruptor|endocrine disruption]], [[immunosuppression]], thyroid disruption, and [[neurotoxicity]] in seals and orcas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Krahn|first=Margaret M.|last2=Hanson|first2=M. Bradley|last3=Baird|first3=Robin W.|last4=Boyer|first4=Richard H.|last5=Burrows|first5=Douglas G.|last6=Emmons|first6=Candice K.|last7=Ford|first7=John K. B.|last8=Jones|first8=Linda L.|last9=Noren|first9=Dawn P.|date=2007-12-01|title=Persistent organic pollutants and stable isotopes in biopsy samples (2004/2006) from Southern Resident killer whales|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025326X07002846|journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin|volume=54|issue=12|pages=1903–1911|doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2007.08.015}}</ref>
== Implications ==
=== Offspring Vulnerability === In mammals, maternal factors can be transferred via the [[placenta]], in the [[colostrum]], and in normal milk during lactation. Marine mammal offspring are especially vulnerable during the time when their own immune systems have not yet matured. When females provide milk to their young, they can have a dramatic impact on offspring fitness during [[ontogeny]], as well as when the offspring matures into an adult.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.seaweb.org/resources/briefings/chempol_mammal.php|title=SeaWeb - Ocean Briefing Book|website=www.seaweb.org|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> Female marine mammals pass on most of their [[Persistent organic pollutant|POP]] burden to their first-born offspring, while the calf is in utero and afterwards during lactation. The large amount of [[Persistent organic pollutant|POPs]] transferred to the offspring as well as the fast rate of transfer, can sometimes prove fatal.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://us.whales.org/issues/marine-chemical-pollution|title=Marine Chemical Pollution|website=WDC, Whale and Dolphin Conservation|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref>
=== Male vs. Female === The POP [[Body burden|burden]] carried by male and female marine mammals tends to increase with time until they reach the age of sexual maturity. After that point, the burden in males continues to grow, as they continue to absorb POPs from their food. However, with female marine mammals, the POP burden carried decreases after birth but can then increase until the next reproductive cycle.<ref name=":1" />
