page.title: Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections

revision.text:
'''The Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections''' (abbreviated '''SPNHC''', often pronounced "spinach") "is an international society whose mission is to improve the preservation, conservation and management of [[natural history]] collections to ensure their continuing value to society".<ref name="spnhcweb">[http://www.spnhc.org/] The Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections</ref>
Founded in 1985, the society was created to cater to the needs of those involved in the care, management and development of [[Natural history collection|natural history collections]].<ref name = "20years">[http://www.spnhc.org/media/assets/SPNHC_second_ten_years.pdf] SPNHC: The Second Ten Years (1995-2005) Stephen L. Williams & Suzanne B. McLaren SPNHC Collection Forum, volume 19(1-2), 2005, pp. 1-14</ref> Society activities include annual meetings, the publication of a newsletter, and an active list-serv in which members consult one another about natural history collections management issues. The mission of SPNHC continues to grow, broadly encompassing [[Archive|archival materials]] such as field notes, and new and growing efforts in digitization and mobilization of collections resources.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://spnhc.org/ Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections] * [http://spnhc.org/50/meetings Society for the Preservation of Natural History Collections Annual Meeting Information]
[[Category:International scientific organizations]] [[Category:Natural history societies]] [[Category:International organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:American scientific societies]]

revision.comment: /* Dynamic denudation, bioturbation and soil biomantle formation */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Earth Science Reviews → Earth-Science Reviews
revision.text:
The '''soil biomantle''' can be described and defined in several ways. Most simply, the [[soil]] biomantle is the organic-rich bioturbated upper part of the soil, including the [[topsoil]] where most biota live, reproduce, die, and become assimilated. The biomantle is thus the upper zone of soil that is predominantly a product of organic activity and the area where [[bioturbation]] is a dominant process. Soil bioturbation consists predominantly of three subsets: ''faunalturbation'' (animal burrowings), ''floralturbation'' (root growth, tree-uprootings), and ''fungiturbation'' ([[mycelia]] growth). All three processes promote soil parent material destratification, mixing, and often particle size sorting, leading with other processes to the formation of soil and its horizons. While the general term bioturbation refers mainly to these three mixing processes, unless otherwise specified it is commonly used as a synonym to faunalturbation (animal burrowings).<ref>{{cite book|author1=Schaetzl, R.J. |author2=S. Anderson |lastauthoramp=yes |year= 2005|title=Soils – Genesis and Geomorphology|publisher= Cambridge University Press|place= U.K.|isbn=0-511-11137-1}}</ref><ref name="Johnson, D.L., J.E.J. Domier, and D.N. Johnson">{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.geomorph.2004.08.014|author=Johnson, D.L., J.E.J. Domier, and D.N. Johnson|year=2005|title= Animating the biodynamics of soil thickness using process vector analysis: A dynamic denudation approach to soil formation|journal= Geomorphology|volume= 67 |issue=1–4|pages=23–46|bibcode = 2005Geomo..67...23J }}</ref><ref name="Wilkinson, M.T. and G.S. Humphreys">{{cite journal|doi=10.1071/SR04158|author1=Wilkinson, M.T. |author2=G.S. Humphreys |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2005|title=Exploring pedogenesis via nuclide-based soil production rates and OSL-based bioturbation rates|journal= Australian Journal of Soil Research|volume=43|pages=767–779}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Paton, T.R., Humphreys, G.S., & Mitchell, P.B. |year=1995|title=Soils, a new global view|place= New Haven and London|publisher=Yale Univ. Press|isbn=0-300-06609-0}}</ref>
==One- and two-layered biomantles, soil stonelayers (stone lines)== The biomantle includes the topsoil, or [[A horizon]] of soils, and also, any underlying lighter-colored (E) horizon that may be present. For [[midlatitude]] and [[subtropical]] soils that have typical A-E-B-C horizons and profiles, the biomantle is normally that part above the [[B horizon]]. In gravelly parent materials where soil particle biosorting by animals has led to the formation of a [[stonelayer]] horizon (SL), the base of the stonelayer (SL) defines the base of the biomantle.<ref>[https://netfiles.uiuc.edu/jdomier/www/temp/biomantle.html biomantle] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630151216/https://netfiles.uiuc.edu/jdomier/www/temp/biomantle.html |date=2007-06-30 }}. Netfiles.uiuc.edu. Retrieved on 2011-03-22.</ref> Biomantles with basal stonelayers are two-layered biomantles that form in parent materials with [[heterogeneous]] particle sizes (mixtures of fines and gravels); those lacking stonelayers are one-layered biomantles that form in [[homogeneous]] materials (either sands, loess, or gravels of approximately uniform size). If two-layered, the soil profile horizon notations in midlatitude and some subtropical soils are: A-E-SL-B-C, where the A-E-SL horizons constitute the biomantle.<ref name="Johnson, D.L. 1995">Johnson, D.L. 1995. Reassessment of early and modern soil horizon designation frameworks and associated pedogenetic processes: Are midlatitude A E B-C horizons equivalent to tropical M S W horizons? Soil Science (Trends in Agricultural Science), v. 2, pp. 77–91. (Trivandrum, India).</ref><ref name="Johnson, D.L. 2002">Johnson, D.L. 2002. Darwin would be proud: Bioturbation, dynamic denudation, and the power of theory in science. Geoarchaeology Special Issue, Site Formation Processes in Regional Perspective, v. 17 (1–2), pp. 7–40 and 631–632.</ref>
Since midlatitude type Bt (argillic) horizons are often lacking in [[tropical]] soils owing to an abundance of active and deep bioturbators that move large volumes of soil to the surface ([[ants]], [[termites]], [[worm]]s, etc.), horizon notations are: M-SL-W, where M is the mineral soil (extended topsoil), SL is stonelayer, and W is the underlying weathered or [[saprolite]] zone.<ref name="Johnson, D.L. 1995"/><ref>Watson, J.P. 1961. Some observations on soil horizons and insect activity in [[granite]] soils. First Federal Science Congress, Proceedings, 1960, Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia, v. 1, pp. 271–276.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Williams, M.A.J. |year=1968|title= Termites and soil development near Brocks Creek, Northern Australia|journal= Australian Journal of Science|volume=31|pages=153–154}}</ref> In this tropical soil scheme the M horizon is the main biomantle and the SL horizon constitutes its base. Stonelayers occupy the base of biomantles in many, if not most, tropical soils and in many midlatitude soils. Where present they often function as subsurface “[[French drains]]” for soil-water movements and storage.<ref name="Johnson, D.L. 2002"/>
==Biomantles and hydropedology<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.5194/hess-14-25-2010|author=Lin H. |year=2010|title=Earth's Critical Zone and hydropedology: concepts, characteristics, and advances|journal= Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci.|volume= 14|pages= 25–45}}</ref> processes== Because the soil biomantle is the main zone of bioturbation, it is invariably permeable and of low density. It thus plays several essential hydropedological roles in the environment. For example, it promotes the downward percolation of rainwater and snowmelt through often-abundant biochannels and interconnected biopores. The biomantle also promotes downslope soil-water (throughflow, interflow) movements if it is formed above a clay-enriched Bt (argillic) horizon, or above some other dense subsoil horizon (e.g., duripan, fragipan, etc.) or bedrock – all of which generally function as aquitards or aquicludes to vertical soil water flow. In such cases the stonelayer, if present, can actually function as an aquifer for free water flow. Hence it is not uncommon to see soil water seepage above Bt horizons on slopes where soil stonelayers outcrop. Ground water recharge can occur through any of these biomantle-related processes. Recharge, of course, can also occur when the soil dries appreciably and shrinks, as during droughts, which allows vertical leakage to temporarily occur immediately after drought-breaking rainfalls.
==Pedosphere, critical zone, biomantle interrelationships== The [[pedosphere]], or soil, is the planetary interface where Earth’s five great global ‘spheres’ interact. These are the atmosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere, lithosphere, and pedosphere. The "[[critical zone]]", a recent conceptual framework, encompasses the Earth’s outer layer in which most surface and near-surface life sustaining processes operate.<ref>{{cite journal|bibcode=2006AGUFM.H11G..06J |title=The Biomantle-Critical Zone Model |journal=American Geophysical Union, Fall Meeting 2006, abstract #H11G-06 |author1=Johnson, D. L. |author2=Lin, H. }}</ref> In practice and theory, the critical zone essentially equates to the pedosphere, whereas the ‘biomantle’ deals with the uppermost critical zone, or pedosphere, encompassing its epidermal layer (where most biota live).<ref>NRC (National Research Council). 2001. Basic Research Opportunities in Earth Sciences, National Academy Press, Washington, D.C.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Lin, H. |year=2005|title=From the Earth’s Critical Zone to Mars exploration: Can soil science enter its golden age?|journal= Soil Science Society of America Journal|volume= 69 |issue=4|pages= 1351–1353|doi=10.2136/sssaj2005.0063|bibcode=2005SSASJ..69.1351L}}</ref><ref name="Johnson, D.L. 2005. pp. 11-31">{{cite journal|jstor=3694030|author=Johnson, D.L., J.E.J. Domier, and D.N. Johnson|url=http://ltse.env.duke.edu/files/ltse/publications/Johnson_DL2005%20reflections%20on%20soil.pdf|journal=Annals of the Association of American Geographers|volume=95|pages=11–31|year= 2005|title= Reflections on the nature of soil and its biomantle|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8306.2005.00448.x }}</ref>
==Latitudinal differences in biomantle thickness== In midlatitude soils where most bioturbation is relatively shallow, seasonal, and without many bioturbators, the biomantle is relatively thin, often less than 1–2 m thick. However, in humid tropical and subtropical erosionally stable regions where both greater volumes of soil are biotransfered and deeper bioturbations occur—and bioturbation is year-round and performed by more invertebrate animals (termites, ants, worms, etc.), the biomantle is often thicker, sometimes 5–6 m or more thick.<ref>{{cite book|author=Breeman (van), N. and P. Buurman|year= 2002|title=Soil Formation |edition=2nd|publisher=Springer-Kluwer Academic Publishers|place= Dordrecht-Boston-London|isbn=0-7923-5263-7}}</ref> Where such soils are formed in conjunction with saprolite production, the biomantle is the bioturbated zone above the structured (unbioturbated) saprolite, with its base commonly defined by a stonelayer. In most subtropical and tropical areas where deep and large volume bioturbators dwell, and in some midlatitudes like South Africa,<ref>Fey, M.V. 2009. Soils of South Africa. Stellenbosch University, Stellenbosch, So. Africa. (Craft Printing International, Ltd, Singapore).</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Brink, A.B.A., T.C. Partridge, and A.A.B. Williams|year= 1982|title= Soil Survey for Engineering|publisher= Clarendon Press|place= Oxford|isbn=0-19-854537-1}}</ref><ref>Brink, A.B.A. 1985. Engineering Geology of Southern Africa 4: Post-Gondwana Deposits. Building Publications, Pretoria, S. Africa.</ref> such thick, two-layered biomantles (those with stonelayers) above structured saprolite are very common.
==Whole soil biomantles== In some desert soils, in many mountain soils with moderate to steep slopes, in many recently eroded bedrock soils, and in various other soils, the biomantle constitutes the entire soil. That is, neither soil horizons nor weathering zones underlie the biomantle. Such biomantles are ''whole-soil biomantles''.{{Citation needed|date=May 2012}}
==The biofabric of biomantles== As originally defined,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1097/00010694-199002000-00004|author=Johnson, D.L.|year= 1990|title= Biomantle evolution and the redistribution of Earth materials and artifacts|journal= Soil Science |volume=149|pages= 84–102}}</ref> a biomantle must exhibit at least 50% [[biofabric]]. This criterion denotes small, often pelletized microbiofabric and mesobiofabric produced by invertebrates (ants, worms, termites), usually observed under hand lens or higher magnification (soil thin sections). The criterion, however, becomes moot and irrelevant in the case of megabiofabric produced in some biomantles – namely the cloddy and chunky surface-spoil heaps produced by small-to-large burrowing vertebrates (rodents, badgers, aardvarks, elephants) and by tree uprooting.
==Soil biomantles and archaeology== [[File:Soil biomantle.svg|right|420px]] Apart from a few stratified cave sites—and those rare open-air sites where archaeological materials were deposited so rapidly that bioturbation and resultant destratifications failed to keep pace with deposition, most prehistoric cultural materials of the world reside in the soil biomantle.<ref name="Balek, C.L 2002. pp. 41-51">{{cite journal|author=Balek, C.L.|title=Buried artifacts in stable upland sites and the role of bioturbation: A review|url=http://alliance.la.asu.edu/rockart/scans/Balek.pdf|journal=Geoarchaeology|volume=17|pages=41–51|year=2002|doi=10.1002/gea.10002}}</ref><ref name="Cremeens, D.L 2009. pp. 390-402">{{cite journal|author1=Cremeens, D.L. |author2=J.C. Lothrop |lastauthoramp=yes |year= 2009|pages=390|volume=73|journal=Soil Science Society of America Journal|title= Geoarchaeology of a strath terrace in the upper Ohio River Valley, West Virginia|doi=10.2136/sssaj2007.0151|bibcode=2009SSASJ..73..390C}}</ref> Such materials are thus mixed, and technically and theoretically out of its original context.<ref name="Morin, E 2006. pp. 541-565">{{cite journal|author=Morin, E. |year=2006|pages=541–565|volume=21|journal=Geoarchaeology|title= Beyond stratigraphic noise: Unraveling the evolution of stratified assemblages in faunalturbated sites|url=http://www.tuarc.trentu.ca/~emorin/Morin_Geoarch06.pdf|doi=10.1002/gea.20123}}</ref> Since many cultural materials (cleavers, choppers' core-stones, metates, manos, pestles, etc.) are invariably larger than burrow diameters of most key bioturbators at such sites (small rodents, ants, termites, worms), they settle downward and form a stonelayer, and thus become part of a two-layered biomantle.<ref name="Peacock, E 2002. pp. 91-114">{{cite journal|author1=Peacock, E. |author2=D.W. Fant |lastauthoramp=yes |title= Biomantle formation and artifact translocation in upland sandy soils: An example from the Holly Springs National Forest, North-Central Mississippi, U.S.A. |url=http://alliance.la.asu.edu/rockart/scans/artifactTranslocate.pdf|journal=Geoarchaeology|volume=17|pages=91–114|year=2002|doi=10.1002/gea.10004}}</ref><ref name="Johnson, D.L 1989. pp. 292">{{cite journal|author=Johnson, D.L.|year= 1989|title= Subsurface stone lines, stone zones, artifact manuport layers, and biomantles produced by bioturbation via pocket gophers (''Thomomys bottae'')|journal= American Antiquity|volume=54|issue=2|pages=292–326|jstor=281712|url=http://alliance.la.asu.edu/rockart/scans/GopherJohnsonLompoc.pdf}}</ref> Smaller artifacts (flakes, debitage) often are homogenized throughout the upper biomantle, and commonly observed in recent bioturbational spoil heaps, like those produced by pocket gophers, moles, and mole-rats.<ref name="Bocek, B 1986. pp. 589-603">{{cite journal|doi=10.2307/281754|author=Bocek, B. |year=1986|title= Rodent ecology and burrowing behavior: Predicted effects on archaeological site formation|jstor=281754|journal= American Antiquity|volume= 51|issue=3|pages= 589–603}}</ref><ref name="Bocek, B 1992. pp. 261-269">{{cite journal|doi=10.2307/280731|author=Bocek, B. |year= 1992|title= The Jasper Ridge reexcavation experiment: Rates of artifact mixing by rodents|journal= American Antiquity|volume= 57|issue=2|pages=261–269}}</ref> Beginning with [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]], the earthworm has been recognized as a key bioturbator of soil biomantles and human artifacts on many continents and islands.<ref name="Darwin, C 1881">Darwin, C. 1881. The formation of vegetable mould through the action of worms. John Murray, London, and Appleton, NY, facsimiles published in 1982 and 1985 by U. of Chicago Press, Chicago.</ref><ref name="Stein, J.K 1983">{{cite journal|doi=10.2307/280451|author=Stein, J.K. |year=1983|title= Earthworm activity: A source of potential disturbance of archaeological sediments|journal=American Antiquity|volume=48|issue=2|pages=277–289}}</ref><ref name="Van Nest 2002. pp. 53-90">{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/gea.10003|author=Van Nest, J. |year=2002|title= The good earthworm: How natural processes preserve upland Archaic archaeological sites of western Illinois, U.S.A. |journal=Geoarchaeology|volume= 17 |issue=1|pages= 53–90}}</ref><ref name="Yeates, G.W 1995. pp. 73-74">{{cite journal|author=[[Yeates, G.W.]] and H. van der Meulen|year= 1995|pages=73–74|volume=19|journal=Biology and Fertility of Soils|title= Burial of soil-surface artifacts in the presence of lumbricid earthworms|doi=10.1007/BF00336350}}</ref><ref>Darwin, C. 1838. On the formation of mould. Proceedings of the Geological Society of London, v. 2, pp. 574–576.</ref><ref>[http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/research_collections/research/labs/archaeology/research/geoarch/van_nest/biomantles.html New York State Museum – Archaeology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301085037/http://www.nysm.nysed.gov/research_collections/research/labs/archaeology/research/geoarch/van_nest/biomantles.html |date=2010-03-01 }}. Nysm.nysed.gov (1998-12-01). Retrieved on 2011-03-22.</ref>
==Ancient soil biomantles (Paleobiomantles)== Soil biomantles, and soils, have been forming from the time that life began inhabiting land.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Meysman, F.J.R., J.J. Middleburg, and C.H.R. Heip|url=http://www.vliz.be/imisdocs/publications/113149.pdf|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2006.08.002|pmid=16901581|year=2006 |title= Bioturbation: A fresh look at Darwin's last idea|pages=688–95|issue=12|volume=21|journal=Trends in Ecology and Evolution}}</ref> Although little formal work has been done on this interesting theme, important first steps are being made.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Hasiotis, S.T.|title= Reconnaissance of Upper Jurassic Morrison Formation ichnofossils, Rocky Mountain region, USA: Paleoenvironmental, stratigraphic, and paleoclimatic significance of terrestrial and freshwater ichnocoenoses|journal=Sedimentary Geology|volume=167|pages=177–268|year=2004|doi=10.1016/j.sedgeo.2004.01.006 |bibcode = 2004SedG..167..177H }}</ref><ref>Heinrich, P.V. 1986. Pleistocene and Holocene fluvial systems of the lower Pearl River, Mississippi and Louisiana, USA. Gulf Coast Association of Geological Sciences Transactions, v. 56, pp. 267–278.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Hughes, M.W., P.C. Almond, and J.J. Roering|year= 2009|title= Increased sediment transport via bioturbation at the last glacial-interglacial transition|doi=10.1130/G30159A.1 |journal= Geology|volume=37|pages=919–922|url=http://pages.uoregon.edu/jroering/outgoing/2009HughesBioturbationNZGeology.pdf|bibcode=2009Geo....37..919H}}</ref>
==Dynamic denudation, bioturbation and soil biomantle formation== The biomantle is an organic-rich near-surface layer in which bioturbation is a dominant process, with all other biological and more traditional soil processes normally being subsidiary (e.g., organic matter productions, eluviations-illuviations, weathering-biochemical transformations, wind and water erosions-depositions, freeze-thaw, dilations-contractions, shrink-swell, gravity movements, geochemical-capillary surface-wickings and precipitations, etc.). The expression ''dynamic denudation'' is the sum of all these processes, with bioturbation and organic impacts commonly dominant.<ref name="Johnson, D.L., J.E.J. Domier, and D.N. Johnson"/>
The role of plants in soil formation is undisputedly great, both agronomically and silviculturally, and is well appreciated and reasonably well understood by geomorphologists, pedologists, soil scientists, farmers, gardeners, and others.,<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1071/S98005|author=Gould, S.F. |year=1998|title=Proteoid root mats stabilize Hawkesbury Sandstone biomantles following fire|journal= Australian Journal of Soil Research|volume=36|issue=6|pages=1033–1044}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1139/x89-001|author=Schaetzl, R.J., D.L. Johnson, S.F. Burns, and T.W. Small|year= 1989|title=Tree uprooting: Review of terminology, process, and environmental implications|journal= Canadian Journal of Forestry Research|volume=19|pages=1–11}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Schaetzl, R.J., S.F. Burns, D.L. Johnson, and T.W. Small|year=1989|title=Tree uprooting: Review of impacts on forest ecology|journal=Vegetatio|volume=79|pages=165–176|doi=10.1007/bf00044908}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Schaetzl, R.J., S.F. Burns, T.W. Small, and D.L. Johnson|year=1990|title=Tree uprooting: Review of types and patterns of soil disturbance|journal=Physical Geography|volume=11|pages=277–291}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8306.2006.00476.x|author=Phillips, J.D. and D.A. Marion. 2006|title= Biomechanical effects of trees on soil and regolith: Beyond treethrow|journal= Annals of the Association of American Geographers|volume=96|issue=2|pages=233–247|year=2006}}</ref> However, the role of animals in soil formation, and in creating soil and soil horizons, and creating various soil-landscape entities (biomantles, [[Mima mounds]], stone lines, etc.), has poorly understood until recently.<ref name="Johnson, D.L. 2005. pp. 11-31"/><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1086/428808|author=Phillips, J.D., D.A. Marion, K. Luckow, and K.R. Adams|year=2005|title=Nonequilibrium regolith thickness in the Ouachita Mountains|journal=The Journal of Geology|volume=113|pages=325–340|bibcode = 2005JG....113..325P }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.earscirev.2009.09.005|author=Wilkinson, M.T., P.J. Richards, and G.S. Humphreys. 2009|title=Breaking ground: pedological, geological, and ecological implications of soil bioturbation |journal=Earth-Science Reviews|volume=97|issue=1–4|pages=257–272|year=2009|bibcode=2009ESRv...97..257W}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2008.07.001|author=Morrás, H., L. Moretti, G. Píccolo, and W. Zech|year=2009|title=Genesis of subtropical soils with stony horizons in NE Argentina: Autochthony and polygenesis|journal=Quaternary International|volume=196|issue=1–2|pages=137–159|bibcode = 2009QuInt.196..137M }}</ref>
Wilkinson and Humphreys offer evidence that “bioturbation appears to be the most active pedogenic process operating in many soils.”<ref name="Wilkinson, M.T. and G.S. Humphreys"/> While probably close to the mark, research over multiple decades strongly indicates that bioturbation is the dominant process in the upper part of most soils, notable exceptions possibly being [[vertisols]] and [[cryosols]], where shrink-swell and freeze-thaw processes, respectively, appear dominant.
==Three notable bioturbation sub-processes and associated particle comminutions==
Soil bioturbations consist of three upper soil disorganizing and organizing sub-processes that can overlap, and that collectively promote particle abrasions and size reductions, termed "[[particle comminution]]". The three bioturbation sub-processes are ''biomixing'', ''biotransfers'', and ''biosorting''.
''Biomixing'' refers to the kind of soil bioturbations typically caused by surface-, shallow-, and intermediate-burrowing vertebrates, such as rodents (pocket gophers, tuco-tucos, mole-rats), insectivores (moles), mustelids (badgers), canids (wolves, coyotes, foxes), marsupials (marsupial moles, wombats), aardvarks, armadillos, pigs, and other similar organisms. Though animal bioturbations are dominant, tree uprooting is still an important process.
''Biotransfers'' refers to transfers of soil by animals, [[vertebrates]] or [[invertebrates]], either to the surface, within the biomantle, or from lower levels. Biotransfers can be effected by any burrowing animal, but the term is most applicable to deep burrowing, so-called conveyor-belt animals, such as ants, termites, and worms. Termites, for example, may burrow downward many meters into weathered and unweathered parent material to collect moist soil for constructing their surface mounds (termitaria). Ants, particularly [[leaf-cutter ants]], can also biotransfer tremendous amounts of soil to the surface in the process of excavating their innumerable multipurpose subterranean chambers. Enormous amounts of soil and sediment are annually biotransferred onto tropical-subtropical landscapes in this process, and even onto some midlatitude landscapes (e.g., Texas, Louisiana), resulting in notably thick biomantles on stable (low slope) surfaces.
''Biosorting'' refers to particle sorting, typically in gravelly (mixed particle) soils, that leads to the formation of a stonelayer (SL) horizon at the base of the biomantle, which results in a two-layered biomantle. The process begins as animals burrow and only soil particles smaller than their burrow diameters are moved; larger particles settle downward as smaller particles are moved upward from below them. The stonelayer (SL) forms at rates roughly proportional to the numbers of bioturbators and the intensity and style of burrowing. Conveyor-belt soil invertebrates (ants, termites, worms, etc.) are the primary biosorters in most tropical, subtropical, and some midlatitude soils, and thus often produce deep, two-layered biomantles if the soils contain gravels, as many do. Small fossorial vertebrates ([[pocket gophers]], [[mole (animal)|moles]], [[tuco tucos]], etc.), on the other hand, tend to be dominant biosorters in many midlatitude soils, especially [[deserts]], [[prairies]], and [[steppes]]. In more humid areas, like northeastern U.S. and W. Europe, conveyor-belt ants and worms are probably dominant or co-dominant.

[[File:Mixed forest NE-Germany.JPG|thumb|Temperate deciduous forest in Germany just as the leaf canopy is opening]]
'''Temperate deciduous''' or '''temperate broad-leaf forests''' are a variety of [[temperate forest]] dominated by trees that lose their leaves each year. They are found in areas with warm moist summers and cool winters.<ref>Archibold, O. W. 1995. ''Ecology of World Vegetation, London: Chapman and Hall.</ref> The six major areas of this [[forest]] type occur in the [[Northern Hemisphere]]: [[North America]], [[East Asia]],<ref>[http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.30.1.421 Wen, J. 1999. Evolution of eastern Asian and eastern North American disjunct distributions in flowering plants. Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics 30:421-455]</ref> [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Western Europe]] (except [[Brittany]], [[Cornwall]], [[Wales]], [[Ireland]] and western [[Scotland]]), [[Denmark]], southern [[Sweden]] and southern [[Norway]]. Smaller areas occur in [[Australasia]] and southern [[South America]].<ref>Archibold, O. W. 1995. Ecology of World egetation. London: Chapman and Hall. Figure 6.1</ref> Examples of typical trees in the Northern Hemisphere's deciduous forests include [[oak]], [[maple]], [[beech]] and [[elm]], while in the [[Southern Hemisphere]], trees of the genus ''[[Nothofagus]]'' dominate this type of forest. The diversity of tree species is higher in regions where the winter is milder, and also in mountainous regions that provide an array of soil types and microclimates.<ref>Keddy, P.A. 2007, ''Plants and Vegetation: Origins, Processes, Consequences,'' Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK.</ref> The largest intact temperate deciduous forest in the world is protected inside of the six-million-acre [[Adirondack Park]] in Upstate New York.<ref>Montgomery, C.K. 2011, ''Regional Planning for a Sustainable America: How Creative Programs are Promoting Prosperity and Saving the Environment,'' Rutgers University Press</ref>
== Human effects ==
Humans have often colonized areas in the temperate deciduous forest. They have harvested [[wood]] for [[timber]] and [[charcoal]].<ref>Hughes, J. D. 1982. Deforestation, erosion, and forest management in ancient Greece and Rome. Journal of Forest History 26: 60–75.</ref> During the settlement of North America, [[potash]] made from tree ashes was exported back to Europe as fertilizer. This left less than one-quarter of original forests to remain. Many forests are now small fragments dissected by fields and roads; these islands of green often differ substantially from the original forests, particularly along the edges.<ref>Wilcove, D. S., C. H. McLellan, and [[A. P. Dobson]]. 1986. Habitat fragmentation in the temperate zone. pp. 237–256. In M. E. Soul´e (ed.) Conservation B; the Science of Scarcity and Diversity. Sunderland: Sinauer Associates.</ref><ref>Harris, L. D. 1984. The Fragmented Forest: Island Biogeography Theory and the Preservation of Biotic Diversity. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.</ref> The introduction of exotic diseases continues to be a threat to forest trees, and hence, the forest;<ref>Little, C. E. 1995. The Dying of the Trees: The Pandemic in America’s Forests. New York: Penguin Books.</ref> examples include the loss of chestnut and elm. At the same time, species such as deer, which are clearing rather than true forest animals, have expanded their range and proliferated in these altered landscapes.<ref>Latham, R. E., J. Beyea, M. Benner, C.A. Dunn, M. A. Fajvan, R.R. Freed, M. Grund, S. B. Horsley, A. F. Rhoads, and B. P. Shissler. 2005. Managing White-tailed Deer in Forest Habitat from an Ecosystem Perspective: Pennsylvania Case Study. Harrisburg: Audubon Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania Habitat Alliance.</ref> Large deer populations have deleterious effects on tree regeneration overall, but particularly for edible species including yew, yellow birch, and hemlock. Deer grazing also has significant negative effects on the number and kind of herbaceous flowering plants.<ref>Latham, R. E., J. Beyea, M. Benner, C.A. Dunn, M. A. Fajvan, R.R. Freed, M. Grund, S. B. Horsley, A. F. Rhoads, and B. P. Shissler. 2005. Managing White-tailed Deer in Forest Habitat from an Ecosystem Perspective: Pennsylvania Case Study. Harrisburg: Audubon Pennsylvania and Pennsylvania Habitat Alliance.</ref> The continuing pressure to increase deer populations, and the continued killing of top carnivores, suggests that overgrazing by deer will continue to be a significant forest conservation problem. Objective criteria for the restoration of deciduous forest include large trees, coarse woody debris, spring ephemeral, and top predators.<ref>Keddy, P.A. and C. G.Drummond. 1996. Ecological properties for the evaluation, management, and restoration of temperate deciduous forest ecosystems. Ecological Applications 6: 748–762.</ref>
